+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 84.5
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The stench hit me before the light did. That particular brew of urine, sour wine, and the sweat of fifty men who’d spent the night tossing on straw pallets in a room with no windows. I’d learned to breathe through my mouth in the first month, but five years later, my nose still rebelled. I sat up, my back protesting against the stone wall where I’d slept, and felt the familiar constellation of scars across my ribs—a map of survived mornings. Outside, Rome was already screaming. The ludus lay in the shadow of the Esquiline Hill, close enough to the Subura that the pre-dawn racket seeped through our walls like disease. Vendors shouting, babies wailing, the metallic clang of a smith’s hammer beating out the rhythm of the city. And beneath it all, the distant, constant growl of the crowd from the Flavian Amphitheater, even at this hour. They were always there, that beast with a thousand throats, hungry for blood that wasn’t theirs. I reached beneath my pallet. My fingers found the leather-wrapped hilt of my sica before they found my sandals. The short, curved blade was illegal for civilians—Emperor Domitian had banned them in the streets after the last conspiracy—but in the ludus, it was my signature. Not the standard gladius they tried to force on me. The sica was Thracian, like my father, like the hills I’d been torn from when the legions came. Its blade hooked like a question mark, single-edged and wicked. When I held it, I wasn’t just another *damnatus* in the sand. I was Darius, son of Rhaskos, who had fought at the River Hebrus. Or I could pretend to be. “Still fondling that pig-sticker, Thracian?” Marcus, the *doctore*, stood in the doorway, his gut straining against his tunic, the whip coiled at his hip like a sleeping snake. He was lanista-born, never tasted the arena himself, but he knew killing the way a butcher knows meat. I sheathed the sica in its scabbard—I was allowed to keep it, a privilege earned after my third *missio*—and rose. “The gods gave me hands, not hooves, Marcus. I’ll fight with what they recognize.” He grunted, but let it pass. Privilege had limits. “Get to the yard. The new recruits need to see what a survivor looks like. And the Patron’s coming today. Wants to inspect his investment before the September games.” The Patron. Gaius Fulvius Plautianus, a senator’s cousin who’d bought six of us last winter. He’d paid extra for me—my *tessera* showed twelve fights, eight wins, three draws, one loss that had cost me three fingers on my left hand. I was a known quantity, a reliable spectacle. When I died, he’d get a decent return. In the courtyard, the morning light hit like a slap. After the dim barracks, the sky was obscene in its blueness, marred only by the smoke from a thousand hearth-fires painting the horizon brown. The air tasted of iron and baking bread, a combination that still turned my stomach. Four new men stood naked for inspection, fresh from the slave markets. One was a German, yellow-haired and staring at the training posts like they might bite him. Another, a Nubian with shoulders like a bull, already bore the brand of a runaway on his cheek. The others were just boys. I took my place at the sanded circle while Marcus began his lecture on footwork, the same speech I’d heard a hundred times. But I wasn’t listening. I was watching the Nubian. He had the look—jaw clenched, eyes dead. He’d already decided to die. That made him dangerous. The crowd loved a man who’d decided to die, especially if he took someone with him. My sica felt warm against my hip. My father’s blade had been longer, a cavalry weapon, but the curve was the same. He’d taught me the twist, that final quarter-turn that opened a man from groin to gut. The Romans called it dishonorable. I called it efficient. When they’d dragged me in chains to Nicopolis, the blade was all I’d managed to hide, wrapped in oilcloth and buried in my thigh wound. The surgeon who’d stitched me had been drunk. He hadn’t noticed the extra weight. “Darius! Show them the block!” Marcus snapped. I drew. The sica hissed from its scabbard, and I fell into the stance—left foot forward, weight on the balls of my feet, blade held low and close. The German flinched. Good. Fear was the first lesson. I parried an imaginary thrust, letting the curve of the sica guide the enemy’s blade past my ribs, then stepped in, my truncated hand bracing the flat as I made the killing arc. The motion was muscle now, no thought. My body remembered what my mind tried to forget. Marcus moved on to the German, correcting his grip on the weighted wooden sword. I sheathed my blade and leaned against the sun-warmed stone. From here, I could see over the ludus wall to the city proper. A litter passed, its curtains dyed Tyrian purple—senatorial class. Behind it, a mob of clients in threadbare togas scrambled for position, hoping for the morning handout. The great machine of Roman patronage, grinding its gears. We gladiators were just another part of it. We fought, we died, and the Patron’s name was cheered in the stands. He gained *dignitas*, we gained a few more days. The Nubian caught my eye. He’d drifted from Marcus’s circle, drawn to me like a moth to a guttering torch. “You think you’ll live forever with that little knife?” he asked. His Latin was accented, maybe from the desert fringe. “I think I’ll live until I don’t,” I said. “Same as you.” He touched the brand on his cheek. “I think I died already. This is just the funeral.” I’d seen his kind before. The *auctorati*, free men who sold themselves for debt or glory, they at least had hope of *rudis*—the wooden sword of freedom. But slaves like us? We were *munera*, offerings. Our only exit was feet-first. “Then die well,” I told him. “The Patron’s bought good seats. His friends will be watching.” The words tasted like ash. I was becoming Marcus, parroting the logic of the sand. But what else was left? My Thrace was gone, burned for a tax dispute. My family was ash. Only the sica remained, and even it was just borrowed time. A commotion at the gate. The Patron had arrived, flanked by slaves and a scribe with a wax tablet. He wore a toga of dazzling white, the stripe of his order running like a wound down the front. His sandals barely touched the filthy courtyard. I watched him survey us, his property, and I wondered if he saw men or merely moving parts in his political theater. The games next month would honor the Emperor’s latest victory over the Dacians. What better way to show loyalty than to provide quality bloodsport? His gaze lingered on me. I met it, which was insolence, but I’d earned that too. He smiled, thin and cold. “The Thracian,” he said to the scribe. “He fights last, before the *venatio*. Pair him with the Nubian. The contrast will please the crowd.” The scribe scratched. My stomach tightened. The Nubian was fresh meat, unpredictable. He might freeze, he might frenzy. Either way, the script was clear: the veteran puts down the mad dog. A lesson in Roman order. Marcus nodded. The Nubian didn’t react. Maybe he’d already known. The Patron moved on, his retinue swallowing him. The sun climbed higher, baking the courtyard until the air shimmered. Someone began oiling leather armor in the corner, the smell of lanolin sharp and clean. A trainer cracked his whip at the German, who’d dropped his sword again. The city roared on, indifferent. I drew my sica once more, not for show this time. I traced the worn pattern on the hilt, the grooves my father’s fingers had carved over decades. In Thracian, we had a word: *doru*. It meant both ‘spear’ and ‘fate.’ You didn’t choose your weapon. You were chosen by it. The blade caught the light, throwing a sickle-shaped shadow across the sand. Tomorrow, or the day after, I would stand in the arena while the crowd chanted my name—my Roman name, not the one my mother gave me. I would dance the steps they’d beaten into me. And when the Nubian fell, when his blood joined the rest in the sand, I would raise my sica to the Emperor’s box and pretend it meant something. But for now, in this moment, the blade was just steel. And I was just a man who hadn’t died yet, breathing the stench of Rome and counting the hours until I had to kill again.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This is a sophisticated piece of historical fiction that demonstrates strong command of voice, period detail, and characterization. The author successfully creates an immersive first-person narrative from the perspective of Darius, a Thracian gladiator, avoiding the obvious combat scene while maintaining tension and emotional depth. The prose is consistently well-crafted with vivid sensory details that effectively transport the reader to ancient Rome. The opening line immediately establishes atmosphere with "that particular brew of urine, sour wine, and the sweat of fifty men," and the author maintains this level of descriptive precision throughout. The characterization of Darius is particularly strong - he feels authentic as both a hardened survivor and someone clinging to fragments of his identity through his father's sica. The piece excels at integrating historical and social context naturally into the narrative. References to Emperor Domitian's weapon bans, the political theater of the games honoring victories over the Dacians, and the complex patronage system feel organic rather than forced exposition. The author demonstrates solid research without overwhelming the story with period details. The dialogue, while limited, feels authentic and purposeful. The exchanges between Darius and the Nubian, and with Marcus the doctore, reveal character efficiently. The voice remains consistent throughout - world-weary but not melodramatic, observant without being overly philosophical. However, the piece occasionally borders on being slightly overwrought in its metaphorical language ("that beast with a thousand throats," "the great machine of Roman patronage"). While evocative, some phrases feel a touch too polished for the character's voice. The ending, while thematically appropriate, lands somewhat predictably on the existential note one might expect from gladiator fiction. The story successfully feels like a slice of a larger narrative, with references to past fights, future games, and the broader political landscape. The characterization avoids simple stereotypes - Darius is neither noble savage nor broken victim, but a complex individual navigating an impossible system. The pacing is well-controlled, building tension through the introduction of the Nubian and the Patron's visit without rushing toward action. The author shows restraint in not forcing dramatic confrontations, instead focusing on the psychological and emotional landscape of the protagonist. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 83.8
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Cailleach Point Lighthouse** **February 18, 2024** Dear Mam, The gales finally stopped yesterday so the supply boat could get out. I’ve been here three weeks now. The light’s automated mostly, but they still need someone for the foghorn and to check the generator. Work’s fine. The cottage is damp. I’ve patched the worst of it with sealant. I miss the noise of the street. Here it’s just the wind and the gulls. They sound like they’re laughing at you. Tell Kirsty I got her parcel. The biscuits were smashed to dust but the tea towel’s grand. Your son, Callum --- **15 March 2024** Callum, Mr. McAllister from the Northern Lighthouse Board phoned to say you’d settled. I said you’d better have, after all that training. Kirsty’s wee one is walking now, toddling into everything. She sends her love. I’ve sent another parcel. There’s oatcakes, a tin of that soup you like, and a jumper I knitted. It’s the thick wool. I noticed in your last you didn’t mention the other keepers—are you not getting on? You sound tired, son. Remember to eat proper meals, not just tinned peas. Write soon. Mam --- **Cailleach Point** **July 3, 2024** Mam, Aye, the jumper fits. It’s warm as anything. I’ve been here five months now—feels longer. The other keeper, Dougie, he’s on his two-week leave. It’s just me and the birds. They’ve learned my routine. One gull waits on the windowsill every morning, taps the glass with its beak till I feed it scraps. Found something today. Behind the stove, a tile fell out when I were cleaning. It’s three inches square, hand-painted, must be fifty years old. Shows a bit of thistle and what might’ve been a bothy, all in blue and white. The edge’s chipped, like someone’s teething mark were on it. Daft, but I’ve been carrying it in my pocket. Feels like company. The foghorn’s been on three days straight. My head’s ringing. Callum --- **22 October 2024** Callum McIntyre, Don’t you “Mam” me when you’re like this. I spoke to Mr. McAllister last week. He said you’ve refused your leave twice now. That’s not right. I know you, you’re being stubborn. That tile sounds lovely but you can’t make friends with broken pottery. Your cousin Alan would take you out on his boat if you asked. You need people, son. Walls close in. I’m not having you turn into one of them mad keepers from the old stories. Come home for a week. I’ll pay the fare myself. The soup was off, by the way. I’ve sent more. Check the dates. Love, Mam --- **Cailleach Point** **December 14, 2024** Mam, Storm’s been here since Tuesday. Took a window pane out the sitting room. I’ve boarded it but the draught’s cruel. The tile broke. I’d set it on the sill and the wind knocked it—smashed clean in three pieces. I sat on the floor and picked up each bit. Couldn’t stop shaking. It’s just a bit of china. I know what you’re thinking. I’m not daft. But when the foghorn stops and there’s that quiet, I hear things that aren’t there. Footsteps on the stairs. The sea’s that loud some nights it sounds like voices. I stood out on the gallery yesterday in the sleet and the drop looked inviting. Just for a second. Then I thought of you and Kirsty’s wean and I went back inside. Don’t phone McAllister. I’ll finish my tour. C --- **January 9, 2025** Callum, I’ve already phoned. Alan’s taking the morning boat out on the 20th. You’ll be on it. I’ve packed your room. Mr. McAllister agrees you’ve done your time—automation’s taking over anyway, he says. You can work the maintenance crew from Oban. Home every night. I’m not asking, son. I’m telling. You’re coming back. That tile—bring the pieces. There’s a man in Dunoon does Japanese repair, kintsugi he calls it. Mends broken things with gold. Shows the cracks are part of the story, not the end of it. That’s you, Callum. You’re not broken. You’re just cracked, and we can mend it. Mam --- **Cailleach Point** **February 2, 2025** Mam, I’m writing this from the boat, can hardly read my own hand. Alan’s at the wheel, giving me privacy but staying close. He’s a good lad. I left the tile on the keeper’s desk. Didn’t take the pieces. I mended it myself, with gold leaf from the emergency kit. Looks bonnie—three gold lines holding it together. Left it for the next poor sod, with a note: “It’s just loneliness. It passes.” You were right about the walls. But you were also right about the mending. I’m not the same lad who left last year. I’m quieter, I think. More comfortable with the quiet now. But I’m ready for noise again. For Kirsty’s wean crying and your kettle whistling and the sound of a bus. See you at the pier. Your son, Callum
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully fulfills the prompt requirements, presenting a correspondence between Scottish lighthouse keeper Callum and his mother over the course of nearly a year. The story traces Callum's psychological journey from initial adjustment through dangerous isolation to rescue and recovery. The characterization is particularly strong. Callum's voice feels authentically working-class Scottish without resorting to heavy dialect or stereotypes. His letters show a gradual deterioration through subtle changes in tone and content - from practical updates to increasingly fragmented observations about gulls and broken tiles. The mother's voice is equally distinct, shifting from gentle concern to firm intervention, demonstrating maternal wisdom and decisive action. The central metaphor of the broken tile works effectively on multiple levels - as a symbol of Callum's mental state, his need for connection, and ultimately his healing. The progression from finding the tile to breaking it to mending it provides strong structural backbone to the narrative. The writing demonstrates restraint and authenticity. Details like "biscuits were smashed to dust," the gull tapping on glass, and the mother's practical concerns about eating properly feel lived-in and real. The isolation is conveyed through concrete details rather than overwrought descriptions. However, some elements feel slightly convenient. The mother's knowledge of kintsugi repair techniques seems somewhat incongruous for her character and setting, though it serves the metaphorical structure well. The resolution, while emotionally satisfying, moves perhaps too quickly from crisis to recovery. The emotional arc is well-constructed, building genuine tension around Callum's deteriorating mental state before the mother's intervention. The final letter strikes an appropriate balance - acknowledging lasting change while suggesting hope and healing. The prose maintains consistent quality throughout, with each character's distinct voice clearly maintained across the correspondence timeline. The story avoids sentimentality while achieving genuine emotional resonance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hostess's smile is a social protocol I recognize but can't fully parse—default greeting, customer service handshake, no authentication required. I follow her to the table, my eyes already mapping the restaurant's attack surface. POS terminals running on what looks like a legacy Windows build. Staff Wi-Fi broadcasting as "Bistro_Guest_2.4GHz" with WEP encryption, judging by the length of the key on that sticky note behind the register. The password itself is laughably visible: "B1stro2024!" taped right next to the artisanal bread display. Zero-day human error, the most reliable exploit in the book. I force my gaze back to my date—Alex, they/them, profile mentioned software QA, which is why I'm here trying to pretend I don't see the world as a series of vulnerability reports. They smile, and for a moment, the static in my head quiets. "You look exactly like your picture," they say. "That's rare." "Authenticity is important," I reply, then immediately cringe internally. Too stiff. Too much like I'm reciting from a security whitepaper. But Alex laughs, and the sound is genuine. We order drinks. They get an IPA. I get water because alcohol fuzzes the attack surface analysis I can't seem to turn off. The waiter leaves, and Alex leans forward. "So. You mentioned you played Magic." My brain stutters. This is the social equivalent of finding an unpatched SQL injection—an opening I actually *want* to exploit. "Vintage player. Mostly. You?" "Modern. Izzet Phoenix before the bans. Now I'm on some stupid Amulet Titan brew that shouldn't work but does." The relief is physical. We're speaking the same language. For ten glorious minutes, I don't think about the restaurant's network topology or the fact that the waiter just reused my water glass without washing it—a minor physical security violation, but acceptable risk given the context. Instead, we talk about the absurdity of the Reserved List, whether the London Mulligan was a net positive, and if Wizards will ever reprint fetchlands into oblivion. Alex's eyes light up when they describe pulling off a turn-three kill at FNM. I match their energy with my own story about flashing back a Yawgmoth's Will in a casual game that went sideways. This is going well. This is *unnervingly* well. My threat model for this evening didn't account for genuine connection. Then Alex pulls out their phone to show me a decklist screenshot. The lock screen blooms under their thumb—a simple L-pattern swipe. The smudge marks on the glass light up like a fingerprint under UV, a greasy constellation spelling out their PIN in three bright points of failure. It's the most common pattern variant, used by 34% of Android users according to a 2019 study I can't forget. The kind of thing that takes 0.02 seconds to shoulder-surf and maybe five attempts to replicate if you have the smudge map. My fingers twitch. My brain screams *don't, don't, don't* but my mouth is already moving, independent of my executive function. "That's a really insecure unlock pattern." Alex's hand freezes mid-swipe. The screen times out, goes dark. The silence that follows is louder than any alert from my intrusion detection system. "Excuse me?" they say. I can see the social connection dropping packets. The handshake is failing. I'm performing a denial-of-service attack on my own evening. "It's just—" I backtrack, but my brain is already dumping the full vulnerability report. "The L-pattern is in the top three most common. And the smudges. You can read the pattern right off the screen. It's like storing your password in plaintext. If someone shoulder-surfed it, they'd have persistent access to—" "Persistent access?" Alex interrupts. Their voice has gone from warm to WEP-encrypted—crackable, but defensive. "It's my phone. For my personal stuff. Who's trying to break into it?" The question is so innocent it hurts. I could explain about opportunistic attacks, about how personal data gets aggregated, about how a compromised phone is a pivot point to corporate networks, to bank accounts, to identity. I could talk about the time I found a zero-day in a dating app that let me pull location data from any user, how I reported it and got a bug bounty and a non-disclosure agreement that still weighs on me. How the mindset that found that bug is the same one that can't stop seeing the world as a series of open ports and default credentials. Instead, I say: "I'm sorry. That was weird. I have a—" *Curse*? *Condition*? "—a bad habit." The waiter returns with our drinks, a timing-based side-channel attack on my apology. Alex takes a long pull from their IPA, and I watch them recalculate my trust score in real-time. The MTG connection bought me goodwill, but I just burned through it like a misconfigured firewall allowing full traffic. "You're one of those security people, aren't you?" they say. Not angry, but assessing. Running their own penetration test on my personality. "Reformed," I say weakly. "White hat. I report bugs, I don't exploit them. Anymore." "Anymore." The word hangs between us like a found vulnerability waiting for a patch. I should change the subject. Ask about their job, their family, their favorite Ravnica guild. Anything but this. But my eyes keep drifting to that sticky note behind the counter. B1stro2024!. Eight characters, one symbol, one number. Meets minimum complexity requirements. Fails every social engineering test. I could own this network before the appetizers arrive. I could show Alex, prove I'm useful, not just paranoid. No. That's the old mindset. The black hat whispering that information wants to be free, that systems deserve to be broken, that people are just wetware with predictable vulnerabilities. Alex is watching me watch the sticky note. A smile plays at the corner of their mouth. "Let me guess. The Wi-Fi password is bad too." "It's taped to the counter." "Of course it is." They turn, look. "It's always either that or it's the phone number." "The phone number is the default for most small businesses. Attackers know this." "Attackers." Alex shakes their head, but they're still smiling. A crack in the defense. "You can't turn it off, can you?" I think about the moment they talked about chaining spells, the joy in their voice when they described the perfect line of play. How for ten minutes, I wasn't a walking security audit. How I was just someone sharing a hobby. "I can," I lie. "I'm trying." Alex picks up their phone again, looks at the smudged screen. "Okay. If I changed it to, like, a random pattern I'd forget, what's the alternative?" The question catches me off-guard. It's not defensive. It's curious. A request for remediation advice. "Biometric plus a long PIN," I say, trying to keep the lecture out of my voice. "Six digits minimum, non-repeating, non-sequential. And clean your screen. Or use a privacy filter. Or just—" I stop. "Or just accept that if someone really wants in, they'll get in, and your threat model is probably your friends at a party, not a dedicated attacker." "Threat model," Alex repeats. "You really do sound like a whitepaper." "I know. I'm working on it." The waiter comes for our order. Alex gets the salmon. I get the pasta. The normalcy of the transaction feels like a successful exploit against my own anxiety. When the waiter leaves, Alex slides their phone across the table. "Show me," they say. "Show you what?" "How bad it is. The pattern." I stare at the phone like it's a live grenade. "That's—I'd have to—no. That's a violation." "Of your ethics?" "Of your privacy." Alex laughs, and this time it's genuine again. "You just told me my privacy was already violated by my own fingers. Show me. Consider it a paid engagement." They haven't paid me anything. The date hasn't even split the check yet. But they're offering a handshake, a trust fall. An invitation into their system. I pick up the phone, holding it like a specimen. The smudges are clear as day under the restaurant's LED lights. Three swipes, four at most. I trace the pattern without unlocking it, just mapping the theoretical attack. "See these?" I point to the bright spots. "That's your entry and exit point. The grease from your thumb never lies." Alex leans in close, and I can smell their shampoo, something with cedar. My brain tries to log the scent as data, but I force it back to the moment. "Okay," they say. "That's actually pretty obvious now that you point it out. Creepy, but obvious." I hand the phone back. Our fingers brush. No exploit, just contact. "So," Alex says, pocketing the device. "Tell me about the worst system you've ever seen. The most insecure." It's a peace offering. A redirect to my safe zone, but on their terms. I think about the restaurant's POS, the WEP Wi-Fi, the sticky note. But that's boring. Low-hanging fruit. "Once," I say, "I found a dating app that stored every user's messages in plaintext. Including the metadata about who liked who. You could reconstruct someone's entire romantic history with a single API call." Alex winces. "That's worse than my phone pattern." "Much worse." "Did you fix it?" "I reported it. They patched it. Gave me a bounty." I pause. "Bought a Black Lotus with it." Alex's eyes go wide. "A *real* Black Lotus?" "HP, not Alpha. But yes." "Okay," they say, picking up their fork. "Now I don't know if I should be impressed or terrified." "Both is usually the right answer," I say. They smile, and for the first time tonight, I don't feel like I'm running a social engineering campaign against my own life. The connection stabilizes. The handshake holds. The waiter brings bread. I don't think about the unwashed glass. I think about Alex's next turn, and whether I can make this game last longer than one night.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and creative concept work. The author successfully captures the voice of a reformed hacker through consistent use of cybersecurity terminology woven naturally into internal monologue. The metaphorical framework is well-maintained throughout, with social interactions described through security concepts ("social protocol," "handshake failing," "trust score") without becoming forced or gimmicky. The character development is particularly strong. The protagonist feels authentic - their compulsive security analysis reads as genuine neurodivergent behavior rather than a surface-level quirk. The internal conflict between wanting human connection and being unable to turn off their analytical mindset creates compelling tension. Alex is also well-realized for a supporting character, showing genuine personality through their reactions and dialogue. The story structure works effectively, building tension through the phone pattern observation and then finding a believable path to reconciliation. The Magic: The Gathering shared interest provides realistic bonding that feels earned rather than convenient. The recovery from the social faux pas is handled with nuance - Alex's response feels genuine, and the protagonist's fumbling attempts at damage control ring true. The prose quality is high, with technical terminology integrated smoothly into natural-sounding internal monologue. The author avoids both oversimplification and excessive jargon, striking a balance that makes the specialized knowledge accessible. Sensory details are deployed effectively without overwhelming the narrative. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the metaphorical framework threatens to overshadow character development, and the ending, while satisfying, perhaps resolves the central tension slightly too neatly. The piece also could have explored the protagonist's past "black hat" activities more deeply to add additional complexity. The dialogue serves its purpose well, feeling natural and advancing both plot and character development. The emotional progression from anxiety to connection to crisis to tentative reconciliation feels earned and authentic. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 90.0
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The ammonia hits first. Sharp, chemical, the smell of someone trying too hard to make things clean. Like when Mom scrubs the bathroom after I’ve been sick, that acrid cloud that says *we’re fixing this, we’re fixing you*. It’s coming from the hallway, where the janitor must have mopped, and now it’s invaded our classroom through the vents and turned everything into a hospital. I press my sleeve to my nose but that just traps the smell against my face, so I drop my hand and let it burn my sinuses instead. Better to breathe it in than to look like I’m smelling myself. That would be weird. That would be the kind of thing he’d remember. He’s right there. Three feet away, maybe four. Lucas Chen, with his perpetually messy hair that somehow looks intentional and his notebook covered in doodles of robots that are actually really good. We’re supposed to be building a Rube Goldberg machine for Ms. Hendrix’s physics unit, and somehow—through what cosmic conspiracy I don’t know—we’re the only pair without a third person. Just me and him and this table strewn with marbles and dominoes and pulleys that I can’t concentrate on because my brain has decided to dedicate all available RAM to not being a disaster. Okay. Opening line. Something casual, intelligent, not try-hard. *So what’s your design philosophy?* No. That sounds like I’m interviewing him for a documentary. *The inclined plane seems promising.* Too robotic. I’ll sound like a textbook that grew legs. *I like your robot drawings.* Desperate. Obvious. Might as well wear a sign that says I’VE BEEN STALKING YOUR NOTEBOOK. My hand moves toward a wooden ramp, but I stop mid-reach because what if my fingers look weird? What if I grab it wrong, with too much force, and he thinks I’m aggressive? Or too tentative, and he thinks I’m incompetent? The ramp sits there, innocent, while I hover my hand above it like I’m performing some sacred ritual. I settle for nudging it slightly with my knuckle. There. Neutral. Efficient. Not weird. The ammonia spikes again, making my eyes water. I blink hard, but now I’m worried blinking looks suspicious. Excessive blinking is a documented sign of nervousness. I read that in a psychology article last month. So now I have to consciously control my blink rate, which is impossible, because the more you think about blinking the more your eyes feel like sandpaper. I’m going to blink. I’m going to blink and he’s going to notice and he’ll know, he’ll just *know* that my palms are sweating through my sweater and that I practiced conversation starters in my bathroom mirror last night. Lucas picks up a marble, rolls it between his fingers. His hands are nice. That’s a weird thing to notice. Hands are just hands. But his are clean with short nails, not bitten down like mine, and there’s a small scar on his thumb that I want to ask about. *How’d you get that?* Simple. Direct. Shows I’m observant but not creepy. Except what if it’s from something traumatic? What if his dog died and that’s the scar and I’ve just ripped open a wound? Or what if it’s from something dumb, like cutting a bagel, and I’ve revealed that I’ve spent time analyzing his thumb? I should say something about the project. That’s safe. That’s why we’re here. “The transfer of potential energy to kinetic energy,” I start, but my voice comes out too loud, too formal, like I’m giving a TED Talk to an empty room. Lucas looks up. His eyes are brown, which I knew, but up close they have these flecks of amber that catch the fluorescent lights. I’ve lost my train of thought. What was I saying? Energy. Right. “Is, um. Important.” Brilliant. Pulitzer Prize-winning discourse. My internal voice—the one that’s currently screaming *abort mission, you sound like a malfunctioning robot*—is so much more articulate than the one that actually leaves my mouth. In my head, I’m witty and insightful. In my head, I could explain chaos theory and make it poetic. Out loud, I’m a glitching Siri. Lucas nods, though. He’s still holding the marble. “Yeah, Ms. Hendrix said the chain reaction has to have at least five energy transfers. I was thinking we could start with a lever that knocks over the dominoes.” His voice is normal. Just completely normal. How does anyone sound that normal? I’m monitoring my own vocal cords like they’re enemy combatants, and he’s just... talking. The unfairness of it makes my chest tight. “Lever,” I repeat. Good. One word. Can’t mess up one word. Except my pitch went up at the end, making it a question, like I don’t know what a lever is. Like I’m confused by the concept. I’m not confused. I’m in the gifted program. I know what a lever is. I know the mechanical advantage formula. I could calculate the ideal fulcrum placement right now if my brain weren’t occupied with analyzing whether I’m standing at a weird angle. I shift my weight to my other foot. Is that too much? Did I just do a full body lurch? I try to make it smooth, but now I’m conscious of my hips, which is a nightmare because hips are inherently embarrassing. Are my hips doing something? I cross my arms to give them a job, but crossed arms are defensive body language. Uncross. Let them hang. But now they’re just... there. Useless meat appendages. The ammonia smell is getting worse, or maybe I’m just more aware of it. It smells like failure. Like every time I’ve tried to talk to someone and ended up with that burning in my throat, the taste of words I couldn’t say. I could mention the smell. Break the ice with a shared sensory experience. *Doesn’t that cleaning fluid smell intense?* But what if he doesn’t smell it? What if I’m just hyper-sensitive because anxiety turned my olfactory receptors up to eleven? Then I’ve drawn attention to my weird nose, and also to the fact that I’m the kind of person who comments on cleaning products. Lucas is drawing something now. A diagram. He’s left-handed, which I didn’t know, and he’s holding his pen in this loose, easy way that makes his letters slant backward in a cool, artistic way. My handwriting is tiny and cramped, like I’m trying to hide it. “Maybe here?” he says, pointing to his sketch. I lean in. Three inches. That’s how far I move. Three inches closer and I can feel the heat from his arm, can see the little nick where he cut himself shaving—no, he’s thirteen, he doesn’t shave, it’s probably just a scratch, stop making up narratives about his face. The diagram is good. He’s labeled everything. “Lever arm,” “fulcrum,” “domino cascade.” His handwriting is loose and confident. Mine would be microscopic next to it. I nod. Nodding is safe. I add a slight “Mm” sound to show engagement but not overwhelming enthusiasm. The “Mm” comes out strangled, like I’m being gently asphyxiated. I clear my throat to cover it, which is worse. Now I’ve throat-clearing, which is a tic, which is weird. “Yeah,” I manage. “That could work.” That could work. The most lukewarm endorsement in human history. I should have said “Great idea!” or “I love the efficiency of that pathway.” Something with exclamation points. But exclamation points are desperate. They’re the punctuation equivalent of trying too hard. So I went with the verbal equivalent of plain toast. Lucas doesn’t seem to notice. He’s already adjusting the ramp, setting up the lever. I should help. My hands are still hovering uselessly. I pick up a domino. It’s light, cheap plastic. I could comment on the material. *These dominoes have a low mass-to-friction ratio.* No. That’s not a thing people say. That’s a thing my brain says because my brain thinks we’re in a lab report. I could say *the dominoes feel flimsy.* But that’s negative. Complainers are exhausting. I read that in a Forbes article about emotional labor. So I just hold the domino. I become the domino holder. It’s a role. I can do this role. Lucas glances at me. “Can you hand me another one?” He spoke to me. Directed words at me, specifically. My name wasn’t attached, but the pronoun “you” was aimed in my direction, which means I exist in his consciousness as a distinct entity. This is huge. This is catastrophic. This means I have to respond appropriately. “Sure.” I hand him a domino. Our fingers don’t touch. I made sure of it. I orchestrated the handoff with the precision of a bomb disposal unit. No accidental contact. No weird lingering. Just a clean transfer of plastic rectangle from my palm to his. He doesn’t thank me. That’s good. Thanking me would mean he noticed the effort, which would mean he noticed my weirdness. The absence of thanks is a gift. I file this away: Lucas Chen does not over-thank. This is data. This is useful. Ms. Hendrix walks by, peers at our setup. “Good progress, you two. Keep it up.” She’s gone before I can panic about whether “good progress” is teacher-code for “you’re behind.” But Lucas smiles, quick and real, and I catch it from the corner of my eye because I’m not looking directly at him. Direct looking is intense. Serial killers look directly. I’m doing a soft focus, a sort of architectural survey of the space he happens to occupy. The ammonia smell is fading finally, replaced by the vague scent of old textbooks and rubber erasers. My shoulders drop half an inch before I catch them. Posture is important. Slouching signals defeat. But ramrod straight is psychopathic. I’m aiming for attentive but relaxed, which is a posture that doesn’t exist. I settle for slightly curved, like a parentheses that’s trying its best. Lucas is saying something about the angle of the ramp. I’m watching his mouth form words, the way his bottom lip sticks out slightly when he’s thinking. I should respond. I have thoughts about the ramp angle. I have *strong* thoughts. The optimal angle is probably 30 degrees, factoring in marble mass and ramp friction. I could say that. I could be helpful. “Yeah,” I say instead. “Angles are important.” Angles are important. I’ve reduced physics to a fortune cookie. My internal voice is composing a dissertation and my actual voice is playing Mad Libs with small talk. He nods, keeps working. I’m both relieved and devastated. Relieved because I’ve survived another exchange without exposing myself as a social cryptid. Devastated because I’ve wasted another opportunity to be the person I am in my head. The marble rolls down the ramp. The lever tips. The dominoes fall in a perfect cascade, click-click-click, and Lucas lets out a small, satisfied sound. I did that. I held the dominoes. I was part of the chain reaction. My heart is hammering against my ribs like it’s trying to escape. My face feels hot. I’m probably red. Red is a betrayal. Red is my body announcing *she’s flustered, she’s weird, she’s thirteen and falling apart over a boy and a marble.* I need to leave before I become a puddle of malfunction. But leaving would be weird. Leaving would require an excuse. I could say I need water. But then I’d have to walk past him, and what if my walk is weird? What if I walk like someone who’s thinking about walking? So I stay. I hold another domino. I monitor my blinking, my breathing, the position of my hips. I catalogue Lucas’s every micro-expression for hidden meanings that probably aren’t there. The ammonia is gone but I can still taste it, metallic at the back of my throat, a reminder that everything clean is also caustic. Inside my head, I’m eloquent. Inside my head, I’m brave. Out here, I’m just a girl holding a domino, waiting for the chain reaction that will finally make me normal.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional mastery of the internal monologue form and delivers a remarkably authentic portrayal of teenage social anxiety. The writer successfully captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of an overthinking adolescent mind through dense, stream-of-consciousness narrative that feels genuinely lived-in rather than performed. The opening with the ammonia smell is particularly effective - it grounds the reader immediately in sensory experience while establishing the protagonist's hyper-awareness and tendency to find metaphorical weight in mundane details. The chemical smell becomes a recurring motif that reinforces themes of artificial cleanliness and caustic anxiety. The characterization is nuanced and psychologically accurate. The protagonist's intelligence shines through her internal voice - she references chaos theory, mechanical advantage formulas, psychology articles, and Forbes pieces - while her spoken words are stilted fragments like "Angles are important." This gap between internal eloquence and external awkwardness is perfectly executed and drives the central tension. The prose demonstrates sophisticated control of rhythm and pacing. Sentences vary from clipped, anxious fragments to longer, spiraling thoughts that mirror the protagonist's mental state. The writer skillfully uses specific details - Lucas's amber-flecked eyes, his left-handed writing, the scar on his thumb - to show how intense observation becomes both connection and torment for someone with social anxiety. The emotional complexity is remarkable. The piece captures not just anxiety but the specific flavor of teenage romantic anxiety - the simultaneous desire for and terror of being known. The protagonist's constant self-monitoring creates genuine tension and exhaustion for the reader. However, the piece occasionally ventures into slightly overwrought territory with phrases like "social cryptid" and "emotional combatants," though these moments are rare and generally well-integrated into the character's voice. The ending metaphor about being "eloquent" inside her head while holding a domino could be seen as slightly heavy-handed, though it effectively bookends the chain reaction theme. The adherence to instructions is excellent - this is genuinely almost entirely internal monologue, captures the rehearsed conversations and second-guessing perfectly, and maintains consistent focus on the group project setting. The word count appears appropriate for the depth achieved. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hallway mirror catches me mid-adjustment, and I freeze. My shoulders are hunched so high they’re practically earrings. I force them down, but they spring back like a trap. *Pathetic.* That’s what she’ll see. She’ll take one look and know I’ve been rehearsing this moment for three days, know I’ve constructed seventeen different versions of how tonight ends, and in sixteen of them, she walks away. I turn from the mirror before it can show me more. The jacket I’ve chosen is wrong—too eager, like I’m trying too hard. But the other jacket is worse, says I don’t care enough. I settle on the wrong one because at least it’s honest. At least it broadcasts *please don’t leave me* in a language she can’t misread. My phone buzzes. *On my way.* Two words, and my chest tightens. *On my way* could mean anything. Could mean *I’m coming to end this.* Could mean *I’m only coming because I feel guilty.* I’ve already drafted my response to the rejection she hasn’t delivered yet: *Fine. I knew this was coming. I never needed you anyway.* That’s the narrative I’m building now—the preemptive resentment. If I can get angry first, maybe it won’t hurt when it happens. Maybe I’ll have the upper hand for once. I picture her face when I say it, the way her mouth will open slightly, wounded. *Good.* Let her feel it. Let her know I’m not some—some *thing* she can just drift away from when she gets bored. But then the other voice, the desperate one, whispers: *What if she’s not bored? What if she’s just tired? What if you’re exhausting?* The mirror catches me again as I pace. I’ve twisted my hands into a knot that would make a sailor proud. I untangle them, but they’re shaking. *Weak.* That’s what shaking hands are. She’ll see them and think *unstable.* And she’d be right. I run through the conversation we’re about to have. Version four is my favorite, the one where she says, “We need to talk,” and I immediately snap back, “About what? About how you’ve been ignoring me for a week? About how you fucked me and then decided I’m too much?” I have that one memorized. I’ve said it out loud in the shower, in the car, into my pillow at 3 AM. Each time, my voice gets steadier, more righteous. More *deserving* of the anger. Version nine is the worst. That’s the one where she’s gentle. Where she takes my hand and says, “I care about you, but…” and the *but* is a guillotine. In version nine, I don’t fight back. I just nod and say, “I understand,” while my insides turn to ash. I’ve practiced that one too, because sometimes you need to know how to be dignified when they’re dismantling you. The knock comes—soft, three taps. Not angry. Not urgent. Just… there. My heart slams against my ribs so hard I’m sure she can hear it through the door. I count to five before opening because opening too fast is desperation, and I’ve already got that in spades. She’s smiling. Not a pity smile—a real one. Her eyes are soft. “Hey,” she says, and leans in for a hug. *This is the part where I ruin it.* I hug back, but my body is a coiled spring. She smells like her shampoo and that perfume I bought her last month. The perfume she’s still wearing. *That means something, right?* Or it means she just likes the smell and I’m reading into it because I’m a fucking psycho who assigns meaning to perfume. “You look nice,” she says, and her hand brushes my shoulder. *Liar. I look like I’m about to crack. You’re just being kind because you’re about to deliver bad news. It’s a softening tactic. I’ve used it myself.* “Thanks,” I say. “You too.” We walk to the living room. She sits on the couch—the *our* couch, where we watched that documentary and she fell asleep with her head on my lap. I sit in the chair opposite because the couch feels too intimate, too much like a place where good things happen that can be taken away. She frowns slightly. “You okay? You seem… I don’t know. Far away.” *There it is. The opening. She’s giving me a chance to confess my instability before she condemns me for it.* “I’m fine,” I say, and I make my voice light, practiced. “Just tired.” She nods, but her eyes stay on me. Searching. I’ve seen that look before—it’s the look people get when they’re trying to figure out how broken you are without having to ask. I want to scream *JUST SAY IT. JUST GET IT OVER WITH.* Instead, she says, “I’ve been thinking about you a lot.” And just like that, the floor drops out. *Thinking about me.* That could mean *thinking about how to let me down easy.* Or it could mean *thinking about how much she misses me.* The two possibilities exist simultaneously, superimposed like a double exposure, and I can’t tell which is real. “I’ve been distant,” she continues, “and I’m sorry. Work’s been hell, and I’ve been in my head. But it’s not about you. I promise.” *There.* The validation. The words I’ve been starving for, dropped right into my lap. My chest floods with warmth so intense it’s almost painful. *She promised.* People don’t promise things they’re about to break, do they? That would be cruel. She’s not cruel. But then: *Or she is cruel, and this is just the setup. The apology before the but. The but is coming. Wait for the but.* “I missed you,” she says, and her voice is so quiet, so honest. I missed you too. The words are right there, but I can’t say them. Saying them would be handing her a weapon. So I nod, and I manage a small smile that feels like it’s cracking my face. She leans forward. “Can I hold your hand?” *What kind of question is that? Why would she ask? Unless she thinks I’m so fragile that touching me without permission might break me. She sees it. She sees the pathetic creature in the mirror.* I extend my hand anyway. She takes it, and her fingers are warm, and for a second—just a *second*—the seventeen versions of this night all collapse into one. This one. The one where she’s here and she’s real and she’s not leaving. But then I feel it: the need to test it. To push. Because if she’s going to leave, better now than later, after I’ve let myself believe. “You’ve been distant,” I hear myself say, and my voice is sharper than I intended. “Like, *really* distant. I figured you were done with… this. With me.” Her face falls. Not in anger—in what looks like pain. “God, no. No, that’s not—” She squeezes my hand. “I’m here. I’m right here.” *She’s here. She’s right here. She’s right here.* The words echo, and for a moment, they’re enough. They’re everything. I could cry with how much I need them to be true. But then the mirror flashes in my mind—my hunched shoulders, my shaking hands. And I think: *She’s here now. But for how long? How long until the distance comes back? How long until she realizes what she’s holding?* I pull my hand away gently. Not a yank, just a retreat. Preemptive. “Okay,” I say. “I just needed to hear it.” She looks at me, and I see it in her eyes: the confusion. The *what do you need from me that I haven’t already given?* And I want to say *everything. Nothing. I don’t know.* But instead I just smile, and I feel the rehearsal starting up again, the next script loading, the next seventeen versions of some future night where I’m back in this room alone, pacing, practicing how to survive the inevitable. She’s still here. She’s still talking. But I’m already halfway to the next rejection, because it’s safer there. Because at least in the rehearsals, I know my lines.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of borderline personality disorder and successfully captures the complex internal landscape of someone caught between desperate need for connection and anticipatory self-protection. The narrative adheres closely to the prompt's requirements, maintaining an almost entirely internal monologue structure while weaving in actual events that contradict the narrator's catastrophic interpretations. The characterization is exceptionally nuanced, showing the narrator's limited self-awareness through moments of recognition ("This is the part where I ruin it") while demonstrating how the compulsive rehearsal of rejection scenarios overrides rational thought. The voice remains consistently authentic throughout—anxious, defensive, hypervigilant, and deeply vulnerable beneath layers of practiced cynicism. The prose strikes an effective balance between accessibility and literary sophistication. Metaphors like "the but is a guillotine" and "my insides turn to ash" enhance rather than overwhelm the narrative. The mirror imagery serves as an effective recurring motif for self-perception and distortion. The piece excels at showing rather than telling, particularly in how it reveals the narrator's condition through their thought patterns and interpretations rather than clinical exposition. The friend's genuine warmth and the narrator's inability to accept it creates palpable tension and cognitive dissonance. The ending avoids false hope or easy resolution, instead showing the narrator retreating back into familiar patterns of anticipating rejection despite evidence to the contrary. This feels earned and true to the psychological reality being portrayed. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly repetitive, though this mirrors the obsessive thought patterns characteristic of the condition. The dialogue, while limited, serves its purpose effectively without feeling forced or unnatural. The emotional complexity is remarkable—capturing not just the pain of anticipated abandonment but also the paradoxical comfort found in rehearsing worst-case scenarios. The reader experiences both frustration with the narrator's self-sabotage and deep empathy for their suffering. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 73.7
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The moon hung like a fractured blade through the temple's collapsed roof, casting jagged shadows across moss-eaten flagstones. Two hundred years of neglect had reduced the once-sacred hall to a crucible of illicit glory. Torchlight flickered from the hands of spectators pressed against crumbling pillars, their faces masks of feverish anticipation. At the center, where a shattered Buddha watched with hollow eyes, two young men stood three paces apart—close enough to smell each other's sweat, far enough to require commitment. Kaito of Jigen-ryū wore his arrogance like armor. His red-and-black armband, silk embroidered with his clan's crest, hugged his left bicep. He stood with his weight forward on the balls of his feet, right hand hovering near his hip in a posture that mirrored the sword-drawing stance his style had evolved from. Every line of his body promised explosive, linear violence. Opposite him, Wei of Piguaquan seemed to vibrate with coiled potential. His own armband, cheaper cotton but dyed the same colors, marked him as champion of the common-born. His stance was lower, knees bent deeply, shoulders relaxed but his hands drifted in slow, unconscious circles—whipping strikes waiting to unfurl. "Your master's prohibition means nothing," Kaito said, his voice cutting through the murmuring crowd. "I will prove Jigen-ryū's superiority where it matters—in blood." Wei smiled, tight and joyless. "Your pride has a price. Let's see if you can afford it." The signal came not from a referee but from the collective intake of breath from the crowd. Kaito moved first, exactly as tradition demanded—explosive, direct, overwhelming. His right foot stamped forward, driving power from his hips as his lead hand shot out in a straight thrust aimed at Wei's solar plexus. The technique, a modified *tsuki*, carried the full commitment of his weight, his body a projectile behind the strike. But Wei's Piguaquan footwork was already devouring space. His left foot slid back at a forty-five-degree angle, his torso rotating counter-clockwise, letting Kaito's fist pass within a finger's breadth of his ribs. In the same motion, Wei's right arm whipped upward from below, a circular *pī* strike that used the momentum of his evasion to accelerate. The edge of his hand cracked against Kaito's temple as the Jigen-ryū fighter's momentum carried him past. Kaito stumbled, his forward drive becoming his enemy. He tucked his chin and rolled with the impact, letting his body fold at the waist. His right hand slapped the flagstones, redirecting his momentum into a low spinning sweep that forced Wei to leap back. The Piguaquan fighter landed three paces away, near a collapsed pillar, his stance already resetting, hands tracing their predatory circles. Blood trickled from Kaito's hairline. He wiped it with his sleeve, his expression hardening. "Fast. But speed without substance is just panic." He advanced again, but this time more measured—two quick steps that closed the distance without overcommitting. His left hand flicked out as a feint, high and straight. When Wei's head slipped right, Kaito's real attack launched: a devastating downward *shōmen* strike with his right, elbow high, body dropping into a deep stance to drive power through his entire frame. The technique was designed to crush bone and end fights. Wei read the feint but recognized the real threat too late to evade cleanly. Instead, he committed to Piguaquan's specialty—meeting force with redirecting circles. His left forearm rose in a tight spiral, not blocking but *guiding* Kaito's descending arm past his left shoulder. Simultaneously, his right foot stepped deep between Kaito's legs, his hip crashing forward to disrupt the Jigen-ryū fighter's base. They became entangled, chest-to-chest. Kaito's eyes widened as his strike's power dissipated into empty air. Wei's right arm, now chambered against his own ribs, snapped forward in a close-range *paoquan*—a cannon fist that compressed and released like a spring. The impact caught Kaito under the sternum, lifting him onto his toes. But Jigen-ryū was born from battlefield necessity. Kaito's training screamed for a disengage, but his pride demanded retaliation. Instead of retreating, he dropped his weight suddenly, his left knee slamming down onto Wei's instep. The Piguaquan fighter hissed, his stance breaking. In that instant of pain, Kaito's forehead snapped forward in a vicious *atama* strike. Wei twisted his head, taking the blow on his cheekbone rather than his nose. Cartilage still crunched. He tasted copper. The force spun him clockwise, away from the pressure, his body flowing with the violence rather than resisting it. He came to rest five paces from Kaito, now positioned near the north altar where moonlight pooled brightest. Both fighters panted, the symmetry of their injuries binding them—Kaito's bleeding temple, Wei's swelling cheek. The crowd had gone silent, the betting forgotten, mesmerized by the purity of the exchange. Kaito advanced again, but caution had infected his pride. He circled left, forcing Wei to adjust his position relative to the altar. The Jigen-ryū fighter's steps were light now, his weight shifting constantly, refusing to plant long enough to become a target. His hands worked in tight, efficient patterns—no wasted motion, every gesture a potential prelude to a finishing strike. Wei mirrored him, but his movement was liquid where Kaito's was mechanical. He drifted backward, letting the distance breathe, his circular footwork never crossing his feet, always presenting an angled target. His hands traced wider arcs, the whipping motions building potential energy with each pass. The decisive moment arrived without ceremony. Kaito saw Wei shift his weight onto his back foot—a momentary commitment. The Jigen-ryū fighter exploded forward, his fastest technique: a sliding *fumikomi* step that carried him across the distance like a drawn sword, his right hand spearing for Wei's throat in a strike that had ended a hundred duels. But the weight shift was bait. Wei had planted his right heel precisely on a cracked flagstone he knew would give way. As it tilted, his body dropped three inches, making Kaito's throat strike pass over his left shoulder. Simultaneously, Wei's entire body uncoiled in a full-circle *pigua*—his right arm whipping up and over in a massive arc that gathered power from his ankles, knees, hips, and shoulders in a seamless chain. The edge of his hand caught Kaito at the junction of neck and shoulder with a sound like a wet towel snapping. The Jigen-ryū fighter's body went rigid, then limp. His momentum carried him forward, but his legs had stopped working. He collapsed at Wei's feet, his face striking the flagstones with a sickening crack. Wei staggered back two steps, his own legs trembling from the effort. He stood over his fallen rival, chest heaving, his right arm numb from the force of the blow. Kaito lay face-down, his red-and-black armband stained darker now, his breathing shallow but steady. The crowd erupted, but the sound seemed distant. Wei looked down at the unconscious fighter, then at his own hands—calloused, common hands that had just toppled a samurai's heir. The temple's shadows seemed to deepen, the weight of generations pressing down. He turned and walked toward the broken doorway, not waiting for the wagered money. Behind him, Kaito's supporters rushed forward, their proud whispers now urgent with fear. The duel was over, but the debt remained—measured not in currency, but in the blood now seeping into the temple stones, feeding the old rivalries that would never die.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence in depicting martial arts combat with exceptional spatial awareness and choreographic precision. The author successfully tracks both fighters' positions throughout the engagement, clearly describing their movements relative to each other and the temple environment. The fight mechanics are believable and well-researched, showing genuine understanding of both martial arts styles. The atmospheric setting is effectively established with the ruined temple providing both mood and tactical elements that influence the fight. The contrast between the two fighting styles and their cultural backgrounds is well-drawn, with Kaito's linear aggression versus Wei's circular evasion creating compelling tactical dynamics. However, the characterization remains somewhat surface-level. While the fighters represent their respective schools adequately, they don't emerge as fully realized individuals beyond their martial arts backgrounds. The dialogue is functional but lacks distinctive voice - both characters speak in similar registers that feel more expository than natural. The prose quality is generally solid with effective combat descriptions, though it occasionally veers toward overwrought territory with phrases like "weight of generations pressing down." The pacing is well-managed, building tension effectively toward the climax. The ending avoids incongruous positivity, maintaining the serious tone established throughout. Wei's victory feels earned through the tactical setup and execution described. The piece succeeds in its primary goal of depicting a visceral, technically coherent martial arts duel while exploring themes of class conflict and traditional rivalry. The writing shows professional competence but lacks the distinctive voice or deeper emotional resonance that would elevate it from skilled genre writing to truly memorable literature. The combat sequences are the clear strength, while character development and dialogue represent areas where the piece could be stronger. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 12.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 11.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The studio mirrors throw my reflection back at me four times over, each one slightly off from the speakers blasting "Love Shot" at 92 decibels—just loud enough that the bass rattles my sternum and makes my inner ear fluid slosh like I'm seasick. I'm positioned stage left, third row, fifth dancer from the mirror-wall, which puts me exactly 2.3 meters from Instructor Park's podium and directly under the southwest speaker that screams the high-hat line into my left temple. "Again!" Park's voice cuts through EXO's harmonies. "From count forty-eight. Isolation sequence. Upper body only." My feet are locked in a parallel second position, heels spaced exactly 30 centimeters apart, toes forward, weight distributed 50/50. This alone is a betrayal—my usual stance is a crouched third-position b-boy ready stance, weight on the balls, knees tracking over my toes, body coiled like a spring. But here, springs are illegal. Everything must be hydraulic. Everything must be clockwork. The count begins. Eight-count intro. On "five-and-six-and," I'm supposed to execute a precise chest pop—forward on the downbeat, retract on the "and"—while my hips remain perfectly still, locked in neutral pelvis. My shoulders must stay depressed, scapulae sliding down my ribcage like they're on rails. The girl in front of me, Minji, does it flawlessly. Her chest isolates as if it's on a servo motor, her hips don't even quiver, her head stays floating above her spine like a balloon on a string. My body wants to wave. Not pop—*wave*. My sternum wants to roll through a liquid curve, let the impulse cascade through my abdominals, drop into my hips, spiral down to my knees. That's how we do it in the Bronx. Energy doesn't stop at artificial boundaries; it flows like water finding cracks. "And!" Park shouts. I pop. Forward. Retract. My hips stay locked. But my left shoulder lifts a centimeter—just a centimeter—on the retraction. A ghost of a pop. Muscle memory from a thousand cyphers where your whole body has to breathe or you die. Park's eyes find mine in the mirror. His reflection is directly behind me, positioned center stage, elevated on his black podium. He doesn't move, but I feel his gaze like a finger pressing between my vertebrae. "Number seventeen," he says. My number here. Not my name. "You're ticking." Tutting. That's what he means. My joints want to make right angles, want to stack and fold like origami. But K-pop doesn't tut. K-pop *is* a tut—every limb a perfect geometric line, every transition a clean 90-degree rotation. My street tutting is reactive, defensive, a language spoken with fingers and wrists against subway tile walls. This is architecture. This is blueprints made flesh. "Again. Slower. Half-tempo." The music warps, the remix stretching "shooting love" into a slurred groan. On count, I isolate my right arm from the elbow—forearm up on one, down on two, while my upper arm remains frozen parallel to the floor. The angle must be exactly 45 degrees. I can see my triceps trembling in the mirror, the muscle fibers fighting the isometric hold. In my neighborhood, we call this "tensing"—bad tension, wasted energy. You stay loose until the moment of impact. Here, tension is the point. You are always *on*. My eyes track Minji's arm in the mirror. Her forearm is a plumb line, a perfect vertical drop from elbow to wrist. Mine drifts 3 degrees inward. My body correcting for the speaker blast that hits my left side harder, throwing off my proprioception. Or maybe that's an excuse. Maybe my body just doesn't believe in this kind of stillness. Park descends from his podium. Three steps.
