+ Teen horror: Tick Tock (Goosebumps) — Score: 78.8
Prompt:
Teen Horror (Goosebumps style) Write a chapter where a middle school student discovers their new smart watch has the ability to rewind time, but doesn't realize that each use is aging them until they notice physical changes (like accelerating through puberty) and that people are treating them differently. They inadvertently cause a timeline shift with disastrous consequences -- and it can only be rectified (maybe?) by reversing the clock once more. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The watch was a hand-me-down from my older brother Trevor, which meant it was either broken, cursed, or both. Mom gave it to me on my thirteenth birthday, after Trevor left for college. “He won’t need it where he’s going,” she said, which I figured meant “the land of adult smartphones.” I should’ve asked more questions. It didn’t look special—just a plain black smartwatch with a spiderwebbed screen. I strapped it on for my first day of seventh grade, hoping it made me look at least slightly cooler than I felt. That’s when I discovered the rewind feature. There wasn’t an actual button labeled REWIND. But during lunch, when I tripped in the cafeteria and my tray went flying—spaghetti spraying like a crime scene, chocolate milk erupting like a volcano—I heard a tiny chime. The watch face flickered. And suddenly, I was standing back at the start of the lunch line, tray in hand, the fall still ahead of me. I froze. Had I… imagined it? But my shoes were still clean. No marinara stains. So I walked more carefully that time, stepping around the puddle. Saved myself from total humiliation. Best. Watch. Ever. For the next week, I used it for everything. Rewinding when I gave a wrong answer in math. Undoing that time I waved at someone who was actually waving to the person behind me. I even reversed an entire conversation where I accidentally called my teacher “Mom.” The watch face would flicker, I’d feel a weird chill, and *boom*—second chance. But on day eight, I noticed the hair. Not on my head—I’d always had hair there. I’m talking about my upper lip. A faint, shadowy fuzz that definitely wasn’t there yesterday. My voice cracked when I ordered a hot dog at lunch, and the cashier asked if I was a high school student trying to scam the middle school discount. I laughed it off. Puberty, right? It hits everyone eventually. But it wasn’t *eventually*. It was *now*. Every time I used the watch, I felt… different. Taller. My jeans stopped reaching my ankles. My sneakers pinched. Mom started asking if I needed new clothes, eyeing me suspiciously like I’d been secretly stretching at night. Even my teachers began treating me differently—Mr. Chen stopped calling on me, like he expected me to already know the answers. Like I was too old to be in his class. Then came the Tuesday that changed everything. I was walking home from school when I saw the car. It was speeding, way too fast for our neighborhood. Mr. Henderson’s golden retriever, Butterscotch, ran into the street after a tennis ball. The car hit him. I heard the yelp, saw the driver’s horrified face, and before I could think, I was hitting that invisible rewind button in my mind. The chime sounded. The world blurred backward. Now I was thirty seconds earlier, standing at the corner. This time, I sprinted into the street, grabbed Butterscotch’s collar, and yanked him back just as the car zoomed past. Hero moment. Except… The next morning, Mr. Henderson’s house was dark. No lights. No barking. I knocked, and his daughter answered. She was crying. “Dad had a heart attack last night,” she whispered. “He’s in the hospital.” My stomach dropped. “But… but Butterscotch is okay, right?” She stared at me like I’d grown a second head. “Butterscotch died two years ago, sweetie. We have a cat now. Muffins.” A cat. Named Muffins. That’s when I knew I’d broken something. I ran home and stared at my reflection. The face looking back wasn’t mine. Well, it was, but older. At least sixteen. Jawline sharper. Acne in places I didn’t know existed. I looked like Trevor’s yearbook photo from tenth grade. The watch flickered. For the first time, I saw it—a tiny countdown in the corner of the screen. **00:04:17**. Then it vanished. Four minutes and seventeen seconds of what? I needed to fix this. Undo the undo. But how? I thought about the dog. About Mr. Henderson. I thought about my own face, aging like a time-lapse video. And I realized the terrible truth: every time I rewound, I was paying with my own time. My own life. Skipping forward, borrowing from my future self. But if I reversed the reversal… would that fix the timeline? It was worth a try. I stood in my bedroom, closed my eyes, and focused on that moment—tripping with the spaghetti. The original mistake. The first time I’d used it. *Chime.* The world rewound. Fast. I saw days blur past in seconds. Felt myself shrinking, felt the hair on my lip dissolve like sugar in rain. When I opened my eyes, I was back in the cafeteria, tray in hand, about to slip on that puddle of chocolate milk. This time, I let myself fall. *Splat.* The spaghetti flew. The milk erupted. Everyone laughed, including me. Because I was just a seventh grader again. Awkward, short, and stain-free in all the wrong ways. I glanced at the watch. The countdown was gone. My reflection in the window looked like me again. Messy hair, baby face, the whole deal. But when I got home, Mom was on the phone, crying. “Trevor’s been in an accident,” she choked out. “A car crash, on his way back from college. They’re saying… they’re saying he might not make it.” My blood turned to ice. I looked down at the watch. It flickered. The countdown was back. **00:00:03.** And this time, it was counting down. Not minutes. Seconds.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the Goosebumps style with its first-person narration, middle school setting, and supernatural premise that spirals into horror. The author demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt, incorporating all required elements: the smartwatch, time rewind ability, physical aging, changing social treatment, timeline disruption, and the necessity of one final rewind. The protagonist's voice feels authentically adolescent, with natural dialogue and observations like "which meant it was either broken, cursed, or both" and "Best. Watch. Ever." The progression from minor embarrassment fixes to major moral dilemmas creates effective escalation. The physical changes are well-integrated into the narrative, showing rather than simply telling how the aging affects the character's life. The story demonstrates creative plotting with the butterfly effect consequences - saving the dog leads to Mr. Henderson's heart attack and timeline changes. The reveal that each rewind ages the protagonist is handled naturally through accumulating physical details. The final twist with Trevor's accident and the countdown timer creates genuine tension and horror. However, the piece has some structural issues. The ending feels rushed, particularly the final revelation about Trevor. The connection between the protagonist's time manipulation and Trevor's accident isn't clearly established, making it feel somewhat arbitrary. The prose occasionally slips into tell-don't-show territory, particularly in explaining the watch's mechanics. The emotional complexity is strong - the protagonist grapples with the temptation of easy fixes versus accepting consequences. The horror builds effectively from social embarrassment to existential dread. The imagery is vivid without being overwrought, particularly in the cafeteria scene and the aging descriptions. Some dialogue feels slightly forced, especially the exposition-heavy conversations, but the internal voice remains consistent throughout. The pacing works well until the final paragraphs, which compress too much revelation into too little space. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 15.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Noir romance: Carnival of Dangerous Intentions — Score: 80.5
Prompt:
Carnival of Dangerous Intentions Coney Island, New York, July 1937. She stopped just before reaching the shooting gallery set up along the boardwalk. It was near dusk, and the carnival lights were buzzing on. **His locks**. The words flashed through her mind, again, like an intruder. Such an old-fashioned turn of phrase that kept surfacing, and something else -- dangerously compelling -- quickly suppressed, lest she question why she had returned here at all. This place where she had promised to meet the stranger -- the young man with the obsidian curls and even darker eyes. She didn't even know his name. Write a scene in a larger story inspired by this prompt. The scene should capture an atmosphere that blends romantic allure with an undercurrent of subtle danger or moral ambiguity. Think 50 shades, but with a more restrained classic sensibility. The scene is all about establishing tension. Write for the feminine perspective. Include roughly 50% dialogue, 20% internal monologue, and 30% exposition and scene setting. The tone should have some edge to it. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The shooting gallery's tinny music scratched at something raw inside her. Evelyn stood just beyond the reach of its electric glare, watching the plaster ducks glide along their rusted track. *His locks.* The words came again, unbidden, a refrain from some half-remembered poem or perhaps just the mind's foolish way of making sense of dark curls that had no business being so perfectly undone. She had seen him only once before—three nights past, at the Copa—and he had looked at her as if he already knew the secrets she hadn't yet whispered to herself. She shouldn't have come. The boardwalk breathed around her, a great lung of salt and humanity. The sun was bleeding out across the water, staining everything amber and rose, and the lights were sputtering to life with an audible hum, like insects drawn to something dying. A barkers' call rose above the surf: "Step right up, test your luck, five cents for a chance at glory!" She could smell the cotton candy—sugar spun into something weightless and false—and it pulled at her, a memory just out of reach. A child's hand in hers. A warning. *Don't let go.* But of what? "You're early." She didn't startle. Somehow she'd felt him approach, a shift in the air, a darkening. When she turned, he was leaning against the weathered railing, one elbow propped, his shirtsleeves rolled to reveal forearms that suggested work—real work, not the soft-handed kind. The obsidian curls fell across his forehead as they had before, and his eyes were indeed darker than the coming night. "And you're watching me," she said, pleased that her voice held steady. "Rather than announcing yourself." "Would you have preferred I call out? Draw attention?" He smiled, but it didn't reach those eyes. "Some things are better done quietly, Miss Evelyn." He knew her name. Of course he did. She felt the thrill of it—a danger she had already accepted. "You have the advantage, then." "Do I?" He pushed off the railing and stepped closer, not quite invading her space but promising he could. "You're the one who accepted my invitation. I didn't know if you'd actually come." "Neither did I." Honesty, she realized, was a weapon between them. His expression shifted, became something almost like approval. "There's a honesty to this place," he said, gesturing to the carnival sprawling behind them. "All appetite and artifice. No one pretends they aren't here to be fooled." "Is that what you want? To fool me?" "I want," he said, and paused, letting the word hang, "to see what happens when you stop pretending." A child ran between them then, clutching a paper cone of that spun sugar, and the scent hit her again—sweeter, more insistent. She was seven, maybe eight. Her father's hand, rough and warm. A man in a boater hat offering her something pink and cloud-like. *Don't take candy from strangers.* But she had. And something had happened. The memory dissolved before she could grasp it, leaving only the metallic taste of warning. "Penny for your thoughts," he said. "They're worth more than that." He laughed, a low sound that seemed to come from his chest. "Everything worthwhile costs more than we expect." He nodded toward the shooting gallery. "Care to try your luck?" "I don't believe in luck." "Then what do you believe in?" She met his gaze fully now, refusing to look away first. "Intention." "Ah." That smile again, sharp as broken glass. "Dangerous things, intentions. Especially here. This whole place was built on them—men who intended to make a fortune off other men's vices, women who intended to marry up, children who intended to disappear into the crowd." He took another step, and now he was close enough that she could smell him—tobacco and bay rum and something underneath it, something wild. "What's your intention, Evelyn?" To feel something real. To stop being good. To let the dark have its way with me. "To see the ocean," she said instead, turning toward the water. "That's what I told myself when I came here." "And now?" She could feel him behind her, not touching, but the space between them seemed to vibrate. The last light was gone now, and the carnival had become a kingdom of artificial stars, each one flickering with its own desperate promise. The shooting gallery's bell rang as someone hit their mark. Cheers went up. False victories. She thought of her apartment uptown, the fiancé who was kind but saw through her, the life that fit like a dress two sizes too small. "Now I think the ocean was just an excuse." "For what?" She turned back to him, and this time she let all the wanting show in her face—the thing she'd been taught to hide, to soften, to redirect into something safe. "For this." He didn't move. Didn't reach for her. The restraint was somehow worse, a violence done to patience. "You don't know what you're asking for." "Neither do you." The barkers call came again, closer: "Every man's a marksman, every shot a chance!" He glanced toward the gallery, then back at her. "One game. If you win, I'll tell you my name. If you lose, you tell me why you really came." "And if I refuse to play?" "Then you leave," he said simply. "And we both wonder what might have been." It was the wondering that would kill her. She knew that already. The slow poison of a life spent at windows, watching other people live. She walked to the counter before she could change her mind, dug a nickel from her purse. The proprietor—a man with three teeth and a tattoo of a mermaid on his forearm—handed her the rifle. It was lighter than she expected, a toy made to feel like a tool. She aimed at the farthest duck, the one painted gold. Her hands were steady. That surprised her. Behind her, she could feel his attention like a hand at the small of her back. "Take your time," he murmured. "The target isn't going anywhere." She fired. The crack was sharp, satisfying. The gold duck wobbled but didn't fall. "Again," he said, and it wasn't about the game anymore. She fired twice more. Missed. The gallery man clucked his tongue. "Tough luck, miss. Care to try again?" She set the rifle down. "I believe I owe you an answer." "You owe me nothing." He was closer again, his voice low. "But I'll take it anyway." The cotton candy scent had faded, replaced by the brine of the tide coming in, the oil from the carousel's gears, the perfume of a hundred strangers seeking their own dangerous intentions. She looked at his face, at the curl that had fallen across his eyebrow, and felt the old phrase rise again. *His locks.* It was from a story, she realized. A cautionary tale about a woman who gave away her strength for a feeling. "I came," she said, each word deliberate, "because you looked at me like I was already yours." The darkness in his eyes deepened. "And are you?" The waves crashed against the pilings. The lights hummed. She could still smell phantom cotton candy, could still feel that small hand in hers, the warning she was finally, gleefully, choosing to ignore. "That," she said, "depends entirely on what you intend to do with me." He offered his arm, a gesture so old-fashioned it made her breath catch. "Shall we walk, Miss Evelyn? And find out?" She took it. The metal of the gallery's bell rang out again—someone else's victory, someone else's loss. She didn't look back.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and atmospheric writing, successfully capturing the requested blend of romantic allure and subtle danger set in 1937 Coney Island. The author establishes an evocative setting with rich sensory details - the "tinny music," "amber and rose" lighting, and "cotton candy—sugar spun into something weightless and false" - that grounds the reader in both time and place. The dialogue crackles with tension and subtext. Exchanges like "You don't know what you're asking for." / "Neither do you." showcase the charged dynamic between characters without overwrought exposition. The mysterious male character is appropriately enigmatic without becoming a cipher, while Evelyn's internal conflict between propriety and desire feels authentic to both the era and her character. The prose strikes an effective balance between period-appropriate formality and modern accessibility. Phrases like "The boardwalk breathed around her, a great lung of salt and humanity" demonstrate literary sophistication without veering into purple prose territory. The recurring motif of "His locks" and the fragmented childhood memory add psychological depth. The pacing builds tension effectively through the shooting gallery scene, using it as both literal action and metaphor for the larger game being played between the characters. The ending appropriately leaves the reader in suspense while providing satisfying closure to this particular encounter. However, some elements feel slightly overwrought - the extensive metaphorical language occasionally threatens to overwhelm the scene's immediacy. The mysterious man's dialogue, while compelling, occasionally borders on the performatively cryptic. The childhood memory subplot, while intriguing, feels underdeveloped and could benefit from clearer integration. The piece largely adheres to the requested structure (dialogue/internal monologue/exposition ratios) and successfully maintains the "restrained classic sensibility" with appropriate edge. The feminine perspective is convincingly rendered throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
