+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 81.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The saxophone sounds like a heart breaking in slow motion, all breathy wails and bent notes that hang in the humid air like lies I've told. I tug my hoodie tighter even though it's ninety-fucking-degrees, because the fabric armor feels necessary down here on Decatur Street, where tourists with frozen Hurricanes stumble past street preachers promising hellfire. Hellfire. As if I didn't just escape some. My stomach growls. That's new. That's *today's* problem, which makes it almost refreshing. I haven't eaten since the truck stop in Mississippi where my ride—some trucker named Dale who talked about his ex-wife for six hours straight—bought me a breakfast biscuit. He'd asked if I was a boy or a girl before we'd even hit the state line. I'd said "waiting for the third option," which made him laugh so hard he nearly swerved into a semi. But he didn't kick me out until we hit the Quarter, until he got a good look at the address I'd scribbled on my hand—some youth shelter I'd Googled at a McDonald's bathroom. His face had changed then, gone all parental and concerned. "You sure about this, kid? This city's got teeth." I'm not sure about anything. That's the point. The saxophone player is ancient and Black and has eyes like he's seen every kid like me come through here since Katrina. He's got a sign that says "VENMO FOR VERACITY" which is either brilliant or bullshit. I drop my last quarter in his case—not because I'm generous, but because the sound is the only thing keeping me tethered to my body right now, and my body is a problem I haven't solved yet. Mom's voice keeps looping in my head: *This is just another one of your patterns, Taylor. The drama.* Like coming out was performance art. Like the way Dad's face crumpled was a special effect. Like my little sister asking "so you're gonna be my brother now?" in that small voice was scripted. I should've waited. I should've— "You're blocking the mojo, new blood." I spin. The girl—*woman?*—behind me is maybe eighteen, with shaved sides and a topknot of dyed-green hair, a septum ring that catches the streetlight. She's sitting on the curb with a sketchbook, drawing the saxophonist in quick, angry strokes. Her fingers are stained with what looks like charcoal and dried blood. "Sorry," I mumble, stepping aside. "Don't be." She doesn't look up. "The tourists are the problem. You got the look, though. Fresh meat." My hackles rise. "I'm not—" "Save it." She snaps the sketchbook shut. "You got anywhere to crash?" The question's a trap. I can feel it. "I've got plans," I lie, and I'm so bad at it that she actually laughs, a sharp, barking sound. "Sure. Plans. The shelter on Chartres? They'll process you, call your folks, ship you back by Tuesday. That's their pattern." She spits the word like it tastes bad. "I'm Remy. And I'm offering you a couch that doesn't come with a social worker." I should walk away. Every instinct says walk away. But my feet are concrete and my options are a shelter that'll rat me out or a street that'll swallow me whole, and Remy's got this energy like she's already survived things I haven't imagined yet. "Taylor," I say. "My name's Taylor." She nods like that tells her everything. "Cool. Come on, T. I know a place with beignets they throw out at midnight." We cut through alleys that smell like piss and magnolias—an actual smell, I swear to God—and she doesn't ask questions, which is how I know she's got secrets of her own. We pass a drag queen adjusting her wig in a broken window, and Remy salutes like they're old friends. We pass a guy selling something in small bags, and she gives him a look that could filet fish. "You always collect strays?" I ask, trying to sound tough. "Only the ones who look like they're running from themselves." She glances at me then, really looks, and I feel my hoodie suddenly become tissue-paper thin. "You got people looking?" The question hangs between us like the saxophone note I can still hear, even blocks away. "My mom," I admit. "She'll call the cops. But she won't come herself." "So it's not the first time." It's not a question, but I answer anyway. "Third. First time I made it out of state, though." The words taste like confession. "First time I told them why." Remy stops at a doorway with a broken lock, pushes it open. Inside is a squat—mattresses, a hot plate, graffiti that says "GENDER IS A GHOST" in spray paint. There's a kid with a lip ring cooking something that smells like ramen and regret. "Crash here tonight," she says. "Tomorrow we figure out if you're worth the trouble." I stand in the doorway, my backpack digging into my shoulders, everything I own in the world. The saxophone is just a memory now, but its last note is still vibrating in my chest, asking the question I can't answer yet: *Is this escape or is this just another pattern?* "Why?" I ask Remy. "Why help me?" She's already moving into the dark interior, but her voice floats back: "Because nobody helped me. And I'm still deciding if that was a gift or a curse." The door closes behind me. I don't know if I've found shelter or just a more interesting way to drown. But for the first time in forty-eight hours, nobody's looking at me like I'm a problem to solve. Just a person. With teeth. I drop my backpack. I stay.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical proficiency and emotional authenticity in depicting a transgender teen's first day as a runaway in New Orleans. The writing successfully captures Taylor's voice through a blend of vulnerability and defensive bravado, using contemporary vernacular that feels genuine rather than forced. The opening metaphor comparing saxophone music to "a heart breaking in slow motion" establishes both the atmospheric setting and Taylor's emotional state effectively. The narrative maintains consistent first-person perspective with natural shifts between present action and internal reflection. The author skillfully weaves Taylor's backstory through organic revelations rather than exposition dumps. Character development is nuanced, particularly in Taylor's conflicted emotions about their situation - simultaneously seeking freedom while grappling with uncertainty and fear. Remy emerges as a compelling deuteragonist with her own implied trauma and protective cynicism. The dialogue feels authentic, especially Remy's street-smart vernacular and Taylor's defensive responses. The New Orleans setting is rendered with sensory details that avoid tourist clichés while capturing the city's contradictions - "piss and magnolias" being particularly effective. The squat's description with its "GENDER IS A GHOST" graffiti provides thematic resonance without heavy-handedness. However, some elements feel slightly convenient - the immediate connection between two damaged youth, Remy's perfect timing and offer of shelter. The pacing occasionally rushes through what could be more developed moments of tension. Some metaphors, while evocative, border on trying too hard ("my hoodie suddenly become tissue-paper thin"). The ending strikes an appropriate balance between hope and uncertainty, avoiding false optimism while providing momentary respite. The transformation from isolation to tentative connection feels earned through the day's encounters rather than artificially imposed. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 79.1
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
"The thing about the apocalypse," said Chewy, in the tone of one who had given the matter considerable thought and found it wanting, "is that it's remarkably consistent." Midas, who was attempting to extract sustenance from a tin can that had expired during the Previous Administration, grunted. This was not agreement so much as acknowledgment that his animatronic companion had, once again, activated his voice box without any obvious power source. It was one of Chewy's more unsettling qualities, along with his permanent expression of mild disappointment and the fact that his fur had long since matted into dreadlocks that smelled of ozone and poor life choices. "Take our current Predicament," Chewy continued, his little mechanical jaw clicking with each syllable. "We are starving, moderately lost, and residing in what used to be a public restroom. This is not substantially different from yesterday, the day before, or that memorable Tuesday three weeks ago when you decided to box that giant radioactive pigeon." "It was stealing our bottlecaps," Midas muttered. "It was *wearing* them as jewelry. There's a distinction. A small one, but in these times we must cling to the small distinctions. They're all we have left. That, and a working definition of what constitutes 'food.'" The graffiti had appeared three days prior, scrawled across a highway overpass in what might have been paint but was probably something more organic and considerably less pleasant: *THE TREES HAVE EYES AND THE EYES HAVE SEEDS. SEEK THE GARDEN OF ETERNAL PROVISION. FOLLOW THE SETTING SUN TO THE METAL HEART.* Midas had interpreted this as a map to a survivalist bunker. Chewy had interpreted it as conclusive proof that hunger causes hallucinations. [1] This was statistically unfair. Midas had also considered the possibility it was a cannibal trap, but had dismissed this on the grounds that cannibals, on the whole, preferred more direct marketing. A simple "FREE FOOD (YOU)" would suffice. "This is a mistake," Chewy said as they set out, Midas carrying his companion in a repurposed baby sling that had seen better decades. "The last time we followed cryptic advice, we discovered that 'The Place of Many Cans' was a recycling center. An empty recycling center." "But the time before that—" "The time before that we found a vending machine. Which contained a single, inexplicably fresh yogurt. Which you ate. Which gave you what historians will call 'The Great Regurgitation of Sector Seven.'" Midas trudged onward. The setting sun painted the ruins in shades of rust and arterial spray, which would have been poetic if it hadn't been so biologically accurate. The "metal heart" proved to be a food truck, its engine block rusted into a sculpture that suggested, to the charitable eye, a cardiovascular organ. The "Garden of Eternal Provision" was the truck's former parking lot, now overrun with kudzu that had achieved sentience and was negotiating for squatters' rights. What neither had anticipated was the bees. Not ordinary bees, which would have been merely fatal. These were descendants of genetically modified pollinators from the Before Time, now the size of golf balls with a collective attitude problem and a legal team. They'd colonized the truck's interior, which did indeed contain provisions: twelve thousand cans of diet soda and one (1) jar of marmalade, which the bees had elected as their constitutional monarch. Midas made it exactly three steps inside before the first bee spotted him. "RUN," suggested Chewy, with the calm authority of a backseat driver. What followed was less a retreat and more a reenactment of that ancient art form known as "flailing about while making noises like a distressed bagpipe." Midas tripped over a parking block, dropped Chewy, and inadvertently discovered that animatronic koalas bounce impressively when thrown with sufficient existential panic. They regrouped behind a fallen highway sign, Midas panting, Chewy clicking reproachfully. "Well," said the koala, after a suitable pause for dramatic superiority, "that went almost exactly as poorly as predicted. The only surprise is that you're not currently being incorporated into hive architecture." "We got the marmalade," Midas said, holding up the jar. It had cost him his left shoe and most of his dignity, but he'd snatched it during his escape. Chewy's LED eyes flickered with what might have been pity. "Midas. My dear, sweet, profoundly dim friend. That is not marmalade. That is bee glue." "It's... what?" "The architectural substrate of their civilization. It's made from tree sap, the dreams of flowers, and the dissolved essence of their enemies. Also, it's low-sugar, which explains the hostility." Midas looked at the jar. Then at his hand, which was already adhering to the glass with the permanence of a bad decision. The journey home took three hours, two hours longer than the outbound trip, because Midas had to stop every fifteen minutes to scrape accumulating debris from his marmalade-hand. By the time they reached the public restroom, he had acquired: one (1) shoe less than he'd started with, a newfound respect for bee urban planning, and seventeen pounds of miscellaneous trash permanently bonded to his right arm. Chewy, who had ridden the return journey in dignified silence, finally spoke as Midas attempted to open the door left-handed. "On the bright side," the koala said, "we're no worse off than we were this morning." "We lost a shoe," Midas pointed out. "Yes, but we gained a jar of industrial adhesive. That's what I call Balance." Inside, the restroom smelled of ozone and regret, which was at least familiar. Midas set Chewy on his customary perch—the sink that still ran, albeit with water that had opinions—and began the arduous process of unsticking himself from his own appendage. "The thing about the apocalypse," Chewy said, settling in for a long night of philosophical condescension, "is that it's remarkably consistent." Midas, who had just discovered his hand was now permanently attached to a comb, could only nod. Some things were universal constants: gravity, entropy, and the fact that no matter how bad things got, they could always get slightly worse in a way that was almost, but not quite, funny. The bees, for their part, appointed a new queen marmalade jar and continued their reign over the Garden of Eternal Provision, which was exactly what it had always been: a nice idea, poorly executed, and full of things that stung.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his dry wit, philosophical observations, and the absurdist humor that defines his work. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both bleak and oddly charming, with the relationship between Midas and Chewy serving as an effective comedic engine. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Chewy emerges as a memorable creation - an animatronic koala with Pratchett-esque wisdom and condescension, whose mechanical nature adds both humor and pathos. His voice is consistently sardonic and philosophically detached, while Midas serves as the perfect foil: hapless, optimistic despite evidence, and prone to poor decision-making. The dynamic between them feels authentic and lived-in. The prose style closely mimics Pratchett's approach with its footnote-style asides, dry observations about human nature, and the way it treats absurd situations with matter-of-fact seriousness. Phrases like "the Previous Administration," "The Great Regurgitation of Sector Seven," and the description of the bees having "a legal team" demonstrate understanding of Pratchett's comedic sensibilities. The story structure follows the prompt precisely: deliberation, mission planning, everything going wrong, and return home worse off than before. The mission itself - following cryptic graffiti to find a food source that turns out to be bee-guarded industrial adhesive - is appropriately absurd and escalates logically within the story's internal rules. However, the piece occasionally feels somewhat derivative rather than truly original. While it captures Pratchett's style well, it doesn't quite achieve the deeper philosophical undertones or the more sophisticated wordplay that elevated his best work. Some descriptions, while colorful, edge toward being overly elaborate without adding substantial meaning. The dialogue serves the story well, with Chewy's voice being particularly strong and consistent. The descriptive passages are generally effective, though they sometimes prioritize cleverness over genuine insight or emotion. The ending appropriately maintains the story's established tone without false optimism. The writing flows naturally and maintains engagement throughout, with the author demonstrating good control over pacing and comedic timing. The world-building, while limited by the short form, feels coherent and lived-in. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16

+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 84.3
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above the door gave a single, apologetic *tink* as Rhys Morgan stumbled into The Book Nook, rainwater streaming from his leather jacket onto the worn flagstones. He slammed the door shut and flattened himself against it, breathing hard. Through the frosted glass, the dark shapes of cameras and shouting figures blurred like angry ghosts. "Well," came a voice from behind the counter, dry as old paper. "That's one way to make an entrance. Bit dramatic for a Tuesday." Rhys turned. She was perched on a stool, a hardcover splayed open in her lap, not even looking at him. Dark hair in a messy bun, glasses sliding down her nose, wearing a faded cardigan that had seen better decades. The name badge on her breast pocket read *Eira*. "Sorry," he panted, running a hand through his soaked hair. "I just—there were—outside—" "Yes, I saw." She turned a page. "They've been camped at the tea shop since breakfast. You'd think the Prince of Wales himself was coming." Rhys straightened, instinctively smoothing his jacket. "Close. Just the Prince of the Box Office." She didn't laugh. Didn't even smile. Just marked her place with a ribbon and finally looked at him, her gaze level and unimpressed. "We have a policy about wet jackets. Hooks are by the door." "Right. Of course." He hung it up, revealing a rumpled linen shirt underneath. "I'm Rhys, by the way." "I know." She climbed down, sliding the book onto a shelf behind her. It was a high shelf; she had to stretch, and her shirt rode up to reveal a sliver of pale skin. Rhys found his eyes drawn there, then snapped them back when she turned. "You're on the side of every bus in Cardiff. Though you're taller in person. Or maybe buses are just small." He laughed, the sound practiced and easy. "You're not a fan, then." "Should I be?" The question caught him off-guard. Most people responded with an automatic *yes*—even when they weren't, they pretended to be, just to keep the moment smooth. This woman was actively refusing to perform. "I don't know," he said, leaning against the counter. "Most people seem to think so." "Most people think a lot of things." She began sorting a stack of books—old ones, with that musty smell he loved. "My mother used to say fame is just a mirror that shows everyone what they want to see. The person in it disappears." Rhys felt something tighten in his chest. "That's... bleak." "She died three years ago." Eira's hands paused on a leather-bound volume. "Lung cancer. Never smoked a day in her life. Just breathed in too much of other people's rubbish, she said. Too much pretending." She glanced up, and for the first time, her expression wasn't neutral. There was a flicker of something—defiance, maybe. "She ran the shop before me. Taught me that the best stories are the ones where nobody's watching." The silence stretched. Rhys felt his usual arsenal of witty deflections evaporate. This was uncharted territory—a woman who'd weaponized her own grief to make him irrelevant. "Well," he said, attempting a roguish smile that felt suddenly hollow, "I can stop watching, if you'd like." "Too late." She'd already returned to her books. "You're here. And you're dripping on my floor." He looked down. A small puddle had formed at his feet. "Right. Sorry. Again." He grabbed a flyer from a wicker basket and began mopping at it, feeling ridiculous. "Look, I don't normally—I'm not just—" "Fleeing the hordes?" She sounded almost amused now. "It's fine. Happened once before. 2017. That boy from the soap opera. He cried in the poetry section." "I don't cry in public," Rhys said, straightening. "It's in my contract." "Shame. Poetry's good for that." She finally stepped out from behind the counter, and he noticed she was barefoot. Of course she was barefoot. It was that kind of shop. "If you're staying, you might as well make yourself useful. There's a box of new stock in the back. Daphne du Maurier reprints. Do you know her?" "Everyone knows du Maurier." "Do they?" She arched an eyebrow. "Or do they just know the films?" Rhys felt the challenge like a physical thing. "I did a period drama in Cornwall. We filmed near Menabilly. I know *Rebecca*." "Do you now." She led him to a back room, cramped and smelling of tea and old paper. The box sat unopened. "Then you'll know it's not a romance. It's a ghost story about a man who can't let go of his dead wife." "And the second wife who can't stop performing for him," Rhys added, surprising himself. "Always trying to be enough." Eira stopped, her hand on the doorframe. For a long moment, she just looked at him—really looked, as if seeing past the jawline and the cheekbones to something that made her mouth soften at the corners. "Well," she said quietly. "Maybe you do read." "I do." He tore open the box, pulling out a copy. "Though I prefer the ones where the rogue gets the girl. More ego-feeding." "Is that what you need?" She was closer now, close enough that he could smell something floral and sharp—lavender and lemon. "Feeding?" Rhys's fingers tightened on the book. The question was too direct, too clean. It cut through the performance like a scalpel. "Doesn't everyone?" "Not from strangers." She took the book from his hands, her fingers brushing his. The touch was brief but he felt it everywhere. "Not from mirrors." "Then what are you?" He hadn't meant to say it. The words just fell out, raw and exposed. Eira held his gaze, and he saw it then—the flush creeping up her neck, the way her throat moved when she swallowed. The cool exterior was a dam with cracks. "Someone who sells books," she said, but her voice had dropped, lost its edge. "Someone who knows that the best rogues are the ones who don't realize they're the hero of their own tragedy." She was so close he could count the freckles across her nose. The paparazzi could have crashed through the window and he wouldn't have noticed. All the practiced charm, the need to be liked, the desperate performance—it all drained away, leaving something simpler and more terrifying. He just wanted her to keep looking at him like that, like he was a man in a small room, not a face on a bus. "Eira," he said, her name feeling like a confession. "Don't." She stepped back, hugging the book to her chest like armor. "Don't do that thing where you make this into a story. Not here." "But it is a story," he said quietly. "Man hides in bookshop. Meets woman who sees through him. It's a terrible cliché." "The best ones are." She almost smiled. "That's why they sell." From outside, the shouting had faded. The hunt had moved on, following some other poor bastard's scent. Rhys should have felt relief. Instead, he felt the loss of the audience. "I should go," he said. "You should." He walked to the front, retrieved his jacket. The bell tinkled as he opened the door. The rain had stopped, leaving the street gleaming and empty. "Rhys." He turned. Eira stood in the doorway to the back room, holding out a paper bag. "For the road. Du Maurier. In case you need something to read on the bus." He took it, and this time when their fingers touched, neither pulled away. "What if I come back?" "Then you'll be a regular customer." She withdrew her hand, tucking it into her cardigan pocket. "And I'll have to charge you." He grinned—the real one, the one that made his cheeks ache. "Would you give me a discount?" "For the Prince of the Box Office?" She was already turning away, but he saw the smile she couldn't quite hide. "Never." The door closed between them. Rhys stood on the pavement, the paper bag soft against his chest, and realized with a jolt of pure, unscripted terror that he didn't need the whole world to like him. He just needed her to stop pretending she didn't.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong craft and execution across multiple dimensions. The Welsh setting is established efficiently through character names (Rhys, Eira) and subtle geographic references (Cardiff, Cornwall) without heavy-handed exposition. The premise is executed naturally - a famous actor genuinely needing refuge creates an organic meet-cute scenario. The character dynamics are particularly well-handled. Rhys embodies the requested "rogue with fragile ego" through his immediate resort to charm when faced with Eira's indifference, and his genuine disorientation when his usual tactics fail. His vulnerability emerges gradually through dialogue and internal observation rather than exposition. Eira's character is more complex - her surface immunity to his charm is believable given her grief and cynicism, while subtle physical cues (the flush, the finger touch) reveal her hidden attraction. The dialogue carries the scene effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Eira's dry, literary wit contrasts sharply with Rhys's practiced charm, and both voices remain consistent throughout. The Rebecca discussion serves multiple purposes - it tests Rhys's authenticity, provides metaphorical depth, and creates a moment of genuine connection. The prose strikes a good balance between literary quality and accessibility. Descriptive elements like "dark hair in a messy bun, glasses sliding down her nose" and "breathing hard" ground us in the scene without overwhelming the dialogue-driven narrative. The writing occasionally approaches purple prose territory with phrases like "angry ghosts" and "weaponized her own grief," but generally maintains restraint. The emotional complexity is well-earned. Both characters have clear motivations and internal conflicts that create genuine tension. The attraction builds naturally through their conversation rather than being imposed by plot necessity. The ending avoids both cynicism and false optimism - there's promise but uncertainty, which feels appropriate for a first meeting. Some minor weaknesses include a few slightly overwrought metaphors and moments where the prose becomes a bit self-conscious. The transformation in Rhys from performer to genuine person happens perhaps slightly quickly, though it's largely justified by his encounter with someone truly immune to his usual methods. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17

+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 85.0
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold door gave with a whisper of disused hinges, not the shriek of alarm Aya had braced for. Beyond lay a vault of stagnant air and whale-oil fumes, the gaslight sconces turned to a miser’s flicker. The silence was a physical thing, pressing against the drumskin of her temples. Even the constant thrum of the harbor above—the clang of winches, the shanties of stevedores—died here, swallowed by the weight of stone and secrets. *Too quiet. Far too quiet.* A foghorn sounded. Once. Twice. Thrice. The mournful blasts bled through the granite like the cries of some leviathan’s ghost, each note a dirge that seemed to mark their steps. Aya’s gloved hand found the leather-wrapped grip of her mother’s athame beneath her coat. The steel was cold comfort. They descended. The stairwell spiraled into the guild’s bowels, its steps worn concave by generations of desperate feet. Katra’s breath was a ragged saw behind her; Simeon’s was the controlled hiss of a man who’d learned silence in the workhouse. Aya’s own heart hammered a counter-rhythm against her ribs, a traitor’s drum. The chamber at the stair’s foot was a cathedral of rust and brass. Pipes snaked along the vaulted ceiling, dripping condensation onto a floor of blackened flagstones. At its centre, upon a plinth of Scythan basalt, sat the artifact: the *Chronicle Cog*, a fist-sized mechanism of impossible geometry, its surface etched with immateria-sigils that seared the eye if looked at too long. Aya had studied its likeness in forbidden texts. It was said to sing the future to those who could hear its frequency. But the cog was not unguarded. Gaslight flared, sudden and cruel. Aya flinched, her hand raised against the brilliance. When her vision cleared, she saw them. Six guards, automatons of brass and whalebone, their ocular lenses glowing with a sickly green phosphor. In their centre, perched upon a throne of salvaged ship’s timbers, was the Spider herself. Mistress Venna. Guild leader. Arrested, the rumor had screamed. Shackled and shipped to the Iron Gaol before dawn. Yet here she sat, immaculate in a waistcoat of burgundy silk, a clockwork pistol of foreign make resting casually in her lap. Her hair was pinned in a severe chignon, not a strand displaced. She looked like a lady of quality taking tea, save for the eyes—black as a drowned man’s and twice as cold. “Ah,” Venna said, her voice the scrape of a blade over whetstone. “The little birds come to roost. Or should I say, the little *sparrow*?” The automatons moved. Not with the jerky motions of common clockwork, but with a fluid, predatory grace. Katra’s knife was in her hand; Simeon’s cudgel rose. Aya had time to think *no, don’t, it’s suicide*—and then the brass fist of a guard caught Katra in the sternum. She went down hard, air exploding from her lungs. Simeon lasted half a second longer before a piston-driven knee shattered his wrist. His cudgel clattered, useless. Aya backpedaled, her athame singing free of its sheath. The immateria churned behind her eyes, a roiling void of whispers and talons. She could call something. A wraith, a shade. Her mother’s ghost, perhaps, to die again in her defense. Before she could shape the thought, the automaton seized her. Brass fingers closed like a vise around her throat, lifting her onto her toes. The athame fell. Her mask—her silk domino, the black sparrow’s beak that had become her sigil—was torn away with a contemptuous flick. The guild knew her only by that mask. By the whispers of the *Sparrow*, who could open locks with a thought and vanish into the immateria’s shadow. Now they saw her face. Aya Morska. Daughter of the late, hanged Lady Elspeth Morska, and heir to one of the harbor’s most ancient, most *pure* bloodlines. Venna leaned forward, elbows on knees, pistol dangling. “Oh, my sweet child. Did you truly think I wouldn’t smell noble stink beneath all that gutter perfume?” Aya’s breath came short. The automaton’s grip was unrelenting. *Think. Think. Mother’s gift is Mother’s curse.* She could feel the blood pooling in her cheeks, the aristocratic pallor flushing with panic. “Let them go,” Aya rasped. “They’re nothing. Guild rats. You know who I am.” “I know exactly who you are, Lady Aya.” Venna spat the title like a curse. “I know the weight of your name. I know the depth of your father’s vaults. I know the price your pretty head would fetch from the Crown, once they learn the Morska line isn’t as *cleansed* of immateria taint as they were assured.” Katra groaned, trying to rise. A boot—human, not brass—pressed her back down. Simeon cradled his ruined wrist, his face a mask of pain and fury. Aya forced her spine straight, despite the choking hold. Her mother’s voice echoed from the gallows: *Pride, daughter. They can take everything but your pride.* “You won’t trade me,” Aya said, each word a struggle. “Not to the Crown. Not when you can use me.” Venna’s eyebrow arched, a perfect crescent of disdain. “The Crown wants me public,” Aya continued, the plan forming even as she spoke, desperate and brilliant. “A spectacle. A hanging to match my mother’s. But you, Mistress… you want the *Chronicle Cog*. You want to know what it sings. And I am the only soul in this city who can read its immateria script without going mad.” It was a lie. Probably. The texts were unclear. But Venna didn’t know that. The guild leader was silent. The foghorn sounded again, a single, lonely note this time, as if questioning. “Brass and oil can’t parse Scythan hex-math,” Aya pressed, her voice gaining strength. “Steel can’t hear the frequencies. But I can. You know what I summoned to crack the Iron Bank’s vault last month. You saw the… residue. Let my companions walk out. Take me. I’ll be your key. Your hostage. Your pet witch. But if you kill them, you’ll have to kill me too, and then you’ll have nothing but a noble corpse and a cog that will rot before it yields.” Venna studied her. The silence stretched, thin as a garrote. Aya could hear the drip of water, the hiss of gas flames, the ragged breathing of her friends. She could hear the immateria, too, pressing against the veil, hungry to be let in. To make a deal. “You bargain well,” Venna said at last. “For a debutante.” She stood, the pistol now aimed at Aya’s forehead. “But you misunderstand your position. You are not the key, child. You are the *lock*. Your mother’s death was a message your family failed to heed. Your continued existence is an embarrassment. But your *capture*—your *unmasking*—that is currency.” She stepped closer. The automaton released Aya. She fell to her knees, gasping, her throat a ring of bruised flesh. “Take them,” Venna ordered. “The girl to the oubliette. The others to the rendering vats. Let them feed the lamps that light our harbor.” “No!” Aya lunged, but brass hands caught her arms, pinioning them behind her. “You need me!” “I need your *name*, Lady Aya. I need the chaos your hanging will sow among the Quality who think themselves above our reach. I need your father to pay handsomely for a body he can bury in consecrated ground.” Venna smiled, revealing teeth filed to points. “The cog can wait. Power is not in artifacts. It is in fear.” As they dragged her back, Aya’s eyes found Katra’s. Her friend’s gaze was hollow, betrayed. Simeon’s was simply empty. The foghorn sounded twice more, final and absolute. Aya thought of her mother, dancing in the immateria wind at the end of her rope. She thought of the dark things she might still summon, here in the deep, if she were willing to pay the price they asked. *Pride, daughter.* But pride wouldn’t save Katra. Pride wouldn’t keep Simeon from the rendering vats. The immateria whispered: *Blood for blood. Soul for soul.* Aya closed her eyes, and began to count the cost.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craftsmanship and atmospheric worldbuilding within the specified "whalepunk" Victorian gothic setting. The author successfully creates a vivid underground world with whale-oil lamps, brass automatons, and industrial maritime elements that feel authentically integrated rather than superficially applied. The adherence to instructions is excellent - all story beats are hit (capture, unmasking, failed negotiation), the confrontation avoids fight scenes as requested, and the piece maintains third-person past tense with appropriate internal monologue. The dialogue captures distinct character voices, particularly Venna's cold, calculating speech patterns and Aya's desperate but intelligent bargaining. The prose strikes an effective balance between atmospheric description and narrative momentum. Phrases like "silence was a physical thing, pressing against the drumskin of her temples" and "voice the scrape of a blade over whetstone" create strong sensory impressions without becoming overwrought. The technical worldbuilding details (Chronicle Cog, immateria sigils, brass automatons) feel organic to the narrative. Character motivations remain believable throughout. Aya's aristocratic background informing her negotiation tactics, Venna's pragmatic ruthlessness, and the power dynamics all track logically. The revelation that Venna orchestrated the "arrest" rumor as a trap demonstrates sophisticated plotting. The emotional complexity is well-handled, particularly Aya's internal conflict between self-preservation and loyalty to her companions. Her final contemplation of the immateria's dark bargain sets up genuine moral stakes without resolving them neatly. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the "arrested leader returns" twist, while well-executed, follows familiar patterns. The ending, while appropriately dark, doesn't quite reach the heights of gothic horror the setup promises. The piece occasionally veers toward purple prose, though generally maintains restraint. The dialogue effectively differentiates characters and advances plot while maintaining period-appropriate formality. Venna's revelation about using Aya's "name" rather than her magical abilities shows strong character understanding and plotting sophistication. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 79.8
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The neon jukebox wheezes its scratchy rock track for the seventh time, distorted guitar bleeding into the humid air of the dive bar. Spike Spiegel slouches in a corner booth, cigarette dangling from his lips, one eye tracking the door while the other—the fake one—stares into his whiskey. He’s been nursing the same glass for an hour, counting the cracks in the vinyl seat. The bounty on Vincenzo Marconi would cover his crew’s fuel costs for a month. Maybe two, if Jet didn’t find another “necessary” upgrade for the Bebop. The door slams open. Revy strides in, twin Cutlasses holstered low on her thighs, dragon tattoo coiling around her right arm like it’s alive. She’s wearing her standard uniform of microscopic shorts and a crop top that defies physics. Her eyes scan the room, land on Spike, and narrow. “Well, fuck me,” she says, voice carrying over the dying guitar solo. “Looks like the circus is in town.” Spike doesn’t move. “You’re blocking the door.” “And you’re blocking my payday.” She slides into the opposite bench, flags down the bartender with a jerk of her chin. “Bourbon. Bottle. Two glasses.” “Planning to share?” “Planning to get drunk enough that shooting you seems like a waste of good ammo.” The bourbon arrives. Revy pours two fingers, slides one across the sticky table. Spike studies it like it might explode. “I don’t work well with others,” he says. “Who said anything about working?” She downs her drink, pours another. The jukebox resets. Same song. Third chord forever stuck in a loop. “Marconi’s mine. I got here first.” “Your watch broken?” Spike finally lifts the glass, lets the liquid burn. “I’ve been sitting here since this shithole opened.” They stare at each other. Revy’s knuckles are white around her glass. Spike’s expression doesn’t change, but his good eye darkens. The cigarette smoke curls between them like a ghost. “How much?” she asks. “Fifty thousand.” “Fuck. Same.” She laughs, harsh and bitter. “ syndicate’s getting cheap. Used to be a guy like Vinny’d pull six figures.” “He’s small time now. Hiding in a place like this.” “Then we agree he’s not worth fighting over.” “Do we?” Revy’s hand drifts toward her holster. Spike’s doesn’t move, but his posture shifts, weight settling into the balls of his feet. Jeet Kune Do ready. Always ready. The bartender, sensing the temperature drop, disappears into the back. “Show me yours,” Revy says, “I’ll show you mine.” Spike raises an eyebrow. She flips one Cutlass, catches it by the barrel, slides it across the table. He does the same with his Jericho. They examine each other’s weapons like they’re reading palms. “Nice balance,” she admits, testing the weight. “You actually know how to use this, or is it for show?” “Try me.” She grins, feral. The dragon seems to breathe. “Bet I can put a hole through that jukebox’s speaker without scratching the neon.” “Bet you can’t.” They move simultaneously, not toward each other but toward the bar. Revy draws first, both guns now, and fires. The left speaker explodes in a shower of sparks. The right speaker—Spike’s target—dies a second later. The song chokes mid-note, leaving only feedback whining through the bar. “Tie,” Spike says. “Bullshit. Mine hit first.” “Your ears work as bad as your attitude?” She’s in his space suddenly, chest to chest, guns still warm. Spike doesn’t flinch. His prosthetic eye catches the neon, glows red. Revy smells like gunpowder and cheap whiskey and something else—adrenaline, maybe. The same thing that’s humming through his veins. “You’re not half bad, Jet Lee,” she says, voice low. “Spiegel.” “Whatever.” She doesn’t step back. “Marconi’s got a room at the Paradise Motel. Room 8. I was going to grab him at midnight.” “So was I.” “Of course you fucking were.” She’s close enough that he can see the scars on her knuckles, the way her jaw tightens when she’s thinking. Spike’s hand drifts up, not to her throat but to the wall beside her head. Caging her without touching. A move that would get most men shot. Revy doesn’t shoot. She leans in. “Motel’s got one entrance,” she says. “We go together, we spook him. We go separate, we might kill each other.” “Option B sounds more fun.” “Don’t flatter yourself, spaceman.” But she’s already moving toward the door, and Spike finds himself following. The night air is thick with ozone and worse things. The Paradise Motel squats two blocks down, its vacancy sign flickering like a dying heartbeat. Room 8’s window glows with TV static. Revy takes the door; Spike covers the window. They don’t need to discuss it. Their instincts align like crossed stars. The door crashes open. The window shatters. Vincenzo Marconi isn’t there—just a looping video feed, a camera, and a note. *Thanks for the entertainment. Wire the money to my account or the footage goes to the syndicate. –V* Revy crumples the note, screaming curses in three languages. Spike checks the bathroom, finds it empty except for roaches and regret. “Fuck!” Revy kicks the TV. It dies. “He played us. Both of us.” Spike lights another cigarette. “Looks like it.” They stand in the wreckage of the motel room, two predators with no prey. The tension doesn’t dissipate—it shifts, becomes something else. Revy’s breathing hard, from anger or something else. Spike’s eye tracks her, the way her chest rises and falls, the way her fingers still twitch near her triggers. “You got a place?” she asks. “Ship.” “Too far.” She sits on the bed, guns on either side of her. Spike stays by the window, smoke curling from his lips. They face each other in the dim light, both armed, both dangerous, both more tired than they’ll admit. “So what now?” Revy says. “Whatever happens, happens.” “Deep.” She kicks off her boots. The dragon tattoo seems to watch him. Spike’s stomach growls, loud in the silence. Revy laughs, sharp and genuine. “You’re broke, aren’t you?” “Starving.” She pulls a protein bar from her pocket, tosses it. He catches it one-handed. “Don’t read into it,” she says. “Just don’t want you passing out before we figure out who screwed us.” They eat in silence, weapons never far. The bed is narrow. The room smells like mold and gunpowder. Outside, the city screams. Revy stretches, cracks her neck. “We could split the fee. Track him together.” “Could.” “But you won’t.” “Will you?” She meets his eyes. For a moment, something soft flickers across her face, like a memory of who she might have been. Then it’s gone. “I’m not a good person,” she says. “Not a bad person. I’m just here.” “Me too.” They’re both lying. They’re both here, in this room, with the weight of their pasts pressing down like a loaded gun. Revy pats the mattress beside her, a challenge. Spike doesn’t move. “Your boyfriend know you invite strange men to motel rooms?” “Fuck you. And he’s not my boyfriend.” “Could’ve fooled me.” “He’s a liability. Like you.” The insult lands like a caress. Spike stubs out his cigarette on the windowsill. Takes out another. Offers it to her. She accepts, lets him light it. Their hands don’t touch, but they could. “Sunrise,” Revy says. “We go our separate ways.” “Fine.” “Try to steal my bounty, I’ll put a hole in you.” “Likewise.” She lies back, guns still within reach. Spike stays standing, a silhouette against the broken window. The night stretches between them, taut as a trigger. Neither sleeps. Neither trusts. But for now, in this room that smells of smoke and stale sheets, they’re both just here. And whatever happens, happens.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and character understanding. The author captures both Spike and Revy's voices authentically - Spike's laconic fatalism ("Whatever happens, happens") and Revy's aggressive vulgarity feel true to their source material. The third-person present tense is handled smoothly throughout, and the 1000-word length constraint is met while maintaining narrative completeness. The story structure effectively builds tension through the initial bar confrontation, the shooting competition, and the motel room revelation. The twist that Marconi played them both adds narrative complexity beyond a simple standoff. The sexual tension is handled with appropriate restraint - present but never overwhelming the character dynamics or plot. Character motivations ring true. Both bounty hunters are broke, competitive, and distrustful, which drives their actions logically. The author avoids having them instantly trust or romantically connect, instead maintaining the psychological distance these damaged characters would realistically preserve. Revy's moment of vulnerability when she offers food to Spike is subtle and earned. The prose style matches the noir/action genre well, with evocative details like "The dragon seems to breathe" and "smoke curling between them like a ghost." However, some descriptions venture toward purple prose territory, particularly the repeated imagery around the dragon tattoo and neon lighting. The dialogue crackles with tension and feels natural to both characters. Revy's profanity-laden speech contrasts effectively with Spike's more measured responses. The competitive banter during the shooting scene particularly captures their dynamic. The story maintains coherence throughout, with clear scene transitions and logical progression. The motel room standoff delivers on the prompt's requirements while subverting expectations through Marconi's absence. The ending appropriately leaves tension unresolved, fitting both characters' inability to truly connect. Minor weaknesses include some overwrought metaphors and a few instances where the prose becomes slightly too self-conscious in its style. The piece also relies somewhat heavily on physical descriptions and smoking/drinking imagery as atmospheric elements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 82.5
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
I still dream about the burial mound sometimes, the way it rose from the pine forest behind Astrid's farm like a whale's back breaking through dark water. In the dreams, I'm always fourteen again, perpetually new to that village where the winters ate the light and silence had weight. But the dream always starts where the memory does: with Astrid's certainty, and my certainty that she was full of shit. That night, she met me at the edge of the forest with a canvas bag that clinked with glass and metal. "You brought the salt?" she asked, not looking at me. Her breath made ghosts in the September cold. "Yes." My voice came out smaller than I'd intended. The salt was in my coat pocket, stolen from my mother's kitchen. Mortons, with the girl in the raincoat. It felt absurdly domestic against what Astrid promised. "Good. And you haven't eaten since sunset?" I nodded. That part had been easy—my mother had made kalops, but I'd pushed the meat around my plate, claiming stomach trouble. The hunger now sat in my gut like a stone. Astrid turned to me, her face pale in the moonlight that filtered through the canopy. "This isn't like the other games, Linnea. With the knot spells and the whispering. This is older. My grandmother said the mound people don't like being disturbed for child's play." "We *are* children," I said, trying for sarcasm, but it came out as a question. She smiled, sharp and knowing. "Not after tonight." The path to the mound was a deer trail, barely visible. I followed Astrid's back, the stripes of her hand-knitted sweater flickering between trees. She'd braided her hair with rowan berries, and I could smell the sharp, sour scent of them mixing with pine resin. My own hair hung loose—Astrid's instructions. "They need to see you," she'd said. Who *they* were remained deliberately vague. The mound itself was bigger than I'd expected. Ten meters across, covered in moss and half-dead heather that rustled like dry bones. A single birch grew from its summit, its trunk twisted in a way that suggested shoulders hunching against a blow. "Sit here," Astrid commanded, pointing to the western slope. "Back to back. Don't speak. Don't turn around, no matter what. If something touches you, don't scream. They hate screaming." "What are we supposed to—" "Receive knowledge." She unpacked her bag: a mason jar of cloudy liquid, an iron nail, a handful of dried something that smelled like rot and incense. "Grandmother said the mound folk remember everything. Who stole, who lied, who spilled blood on their ground. They'll tell us about Emma and her boyfriend. About why Johan's been looking at you in class." She glanced up. "If we pay the price." My stomach tightened. "What price?" "Attention." She poured the liquid—urine, I realized with a jolt, probably her own—around the base of the birch, then drove the iron nail into the earth at what I guessed was the mound's heart. "We sit from moonrise to moonset. We listen. We don't leave." The ground was frozen beneath us as we settled, our spines pressed together. Astrid's back was rigid with anticipation; mine was stiff with fear. The rules ran through my head like a chant: No speaking. No turning. No screaming. Stay until moonset. The moon above was a sickle blade, sharp enough to cut. For the first hour, there was nothing but the cold seeping through my jeans and the sound of our synchronized breathing. I counted my exhales, watched my breath plume and dissipate. This is stupid, I told myself. This is just another of Astrid's stories, like the one about the vittra living in her barn or the church wights that ring the bells when someone lies. Then the birch leaves began to rustle. There was no wind. I know because I'd been watching the trees at the forest's edge, their branches still as stone. But the leaves above us whispered, a dry papery sound that resolved into syllables. Not Swedish. Not any language I'd heard in my fourteen years. The sound seemed to come from everywhere, vibrating through the frozen ground, up my spine, into my teeth. Astrid's back tensed against mine. She'd heard it too. The temperature dropped. My exhalations suddenly fogged thicker, heavier, lingering in front of my face like they had weight and intention. The moss beneath my hands, already brittle, grew sharp with frost. And I felt it: the sensation of being watched not by eyes, but by the mound itself, as if the earth had become sentient and curious and very, very old. A branch snapped in the forest. Then another, closer. Footsteps, deliberate and slow, circling the mound. I wanted to turn, to run, to scream exactly as Astrid had forbidden. My heart hammered against my ribs, a frantic bird trying to escape. "Linnea." The voice was my mother's. Perfect, except it came from the wrong direction—from deep in the forest, where no path led. It called again, worried: "Linnea, where are you? It's past midnight." I almost answered. My mouth opened, breath ready to shape the word *here*. But Astrid's elbow dug sharp into my back, a warning. The church bell chimed. One solitary note, clear and impossible. The village church was three kilometers away, its bell silent after the evening service. They never rang it at night, never for just one chime. The sound reverberated through my chest, and when it faded, the footsteps stopped. Something touched my hair. Not wind. Fingers, or what felt like fingers—cold and impossibly long, combing through the strands with a tenderness that made my skin crawl. I bit my lip until I tasted blood, the pain anchoring me. *Don't scream. Don't scream. Don't scream.* Astrid began to hum. It was a melody I'd never heard, minor-key and ancient, vibrating through her spine into mine. The fingers in my hair paused, then withdrew. The birch leaves fell silent. And the cold that had gripped the mound lifted so suddenly I gasped. We sat until the moon dipped below the trees. When Astrid finally stood, her legs shook. She didn't look at me as she packed her bag, leaving the iron nail in the earth. "Did you get your knowledge?" I asked, my voice raw. She glanced toward the forest, where the footsteps had circled. "Yes." "What did you learn?" "That they know my name." She finally met my eyes, and for the first time since I'd met her, she looked young. "And now they know yours too." We never spoke of the mound again. I left the village two years later for university in Lund, and Astrid stayed, inheriting her grandmother's farm. But sometimes, when the wind is right, I still hear that single church bell, and I know—whether it was real or just the product of two girls scaring themselves stupid—that some doors, once opened, never quite close again.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and atmospheric control in the folk horror genre. The author successfully creates an unsettling midnight ritual scene that maintains the requested ambiguity between supernatural and psychological explanations. The first-person retrospective narration works effectively, providing adult perspective on teenage experiences without being heavy-handed about the framing device. The characterization is solid, particularly Astrid's portrayal as both knowledgeable guide and fellow teenager. Her matter-of-fact delivery of supernatural instructions feels authentic to the folk horror tradition, while Linnea's skepticism and growing fear create appropriate tension. The dynamic between the city girl and local feels genuine rather than stereotypical. The prose quality is high, with evocative imagery that serves the atmospheric needs without becoming overwrought. Descriptions like "the way it rose from the pine forest behind Astrid's farm like a whale's back breaking through dark water" are memorable and fitting. The author maintains consistent voice throughout, balancing teenage vernacular with more sophisticated retrospective observations. The ritual elements feel researched and authentic rather than generic, incorporating specific details like the iron nail, rowan berries, and the significance of facing directions. The supernatural events escalate appropriately - from rustling leaves to impossible sounds to physical contact - maintaining the crucial ambiguity about whether events are real or psychological. However, some elements feel slightly familiar within the genre. The "city teen encounters rural supernatural traditions" premise, while well-executed, doesn't break particularly new ground. The ending, while thematically appropriate, relies on somewhat expected beats about doors that can't be closed. The dialogue, though limited, feels natural and age-appropriate. Astrid's cryptic responses and Linnea's questions serve both character development and plot advancement effectively. The pacing works well, building tension steadily through the ritual without rushing or dragging. The piece successfully adheres to the specific instructions about setting, characters, and the útiseta ritual while maintaining the requested ambiguity and folk horror atmosphere. The emotional complexity emerges through Linnea's conflicted feelings about belonging, rebellion, and the price of knowledge. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The anatomy diagram haunts from the wall—each muscle fiber, each tendon sheath, rendered in clinical detachment. My body knows better. My body knows that the supraspinatus isn’t just a red swoop of ink but a screaming interface between bone and ambition, that the A2 pulley of the right ring finger isn’t a label but a ruptured promise. Kieran’s hands are on me before I’m ready, which is the point. He knows I’ll stall, will let the timer run down discussing weather, his new practice, anything but this. “Let’s assess passive external rotation,” he says, his voice neutral as bank teller’s. “Supine position. I’m supporting your scapula.” I lie back on the treatment table, the vinyl cool through my thin tank top. His left hand slides beneath my shoulder blade, fingers slotting between table and trapezius, his thumb finding the medial border of my scapula. The pressure is precise, stabilizing. His right hand grips my forearm just proximal to the wrist, his thumb overlapping my radius. I fixate on that contact point—warm, dry, the slight callus of his palm a remnant of our shared past on rock faces. “Relax your arm. I’m taking it to end-range.” He flexes my elbow to ninety degrees, then slowly, excruciatingly, rotates my humerus externally. At seventy-eight degrees—he narrates each increment like a goddamn sports commentator—the familiar fire ignites deep in the glenohumeral joint. Not the sharp bite of acute injury but the deep, chewing ache of a labrum that will never be whole again. “Guardianship,” he murmurs, feeling my deltoid tense. “You’re protecting it. Let go.” I exhale through my teeth. His face is twelve inches above mine, his eyes on my shoulder’s alignment, not on me. The sexual tension isn’t in his gaze—it’s in the absolute professionalism of his gaze, the way it renders my body simultaneously object and subject. I hate that I notice the way his forearm muscles contract as he holds my arm suspended, the way his scrub top pulls taut across his chest when he leans. “End-feel is firm,” he says, lowering my arm with controlled deceleration. “Better than last week. Now finger work.” The transition is seamless. He moves to the stool at the table’s head, his thigh brushing my shoulder as he repositions. I flinch—not from pain, from the heat of him through cotton. He doesn’t acknowledge it. Professional distance is a performance we’re both nailing. He takes my right hand in both of his, his fingers interlacing with mine in a parody of intimacy. His thumbs press into my palm, assessing lumbrical tension. “Make a fist. Slowly.” I curl my fingers. The ring finger, splinted for months, tracks crookedly. The repaired pulley—his surgical notes said “harvested palmaris longus graft”—feels like a rubber band stretched too thin. “Now straighten just the DIP joint.” I try. The distal interphalangeal joint resists, locked by adhesions. Kieran’s thumb moves to the dorsal aspect of that joint, his index finger supporting the volar surface. He applies a gentle anterior glide, a millimeter of accessory motion to break up scar tissue. The sensation is nauseating—not pain, exactly, but the cellular memory of falling, of feeling the tendon pop like a guitar string snapping twenty feet off the deck. “Breathe,” he says, though I haven’t realized I was holding it. His hands shift. Now he’s working the flexor tendon sheath, his thumb performing cross-friction massage at the level of the proximal phalanx. The pressure is vertical to the tendon fibers, designed to break up adhesions. It hurts in a way that makes my eyes water, makes my toes curl against the table. My body wants to yank away. My pride keeps it still. “Too much?” he asks, though he knows the answer. He’s watching my face now, the physiotherapist’s calculus of therapeutic pain versus harmful pain playing across his features. “Just right,” I lie. A smile ghosts his lips. He knows me. Knew me. We trained together for six years, before his shoulder gave out early—just impingement, fixable, a blessing that rerouted him into this career while mine ended in surgical steel and permanent restrictions. “PNF pattern next,” he says, releasing my hand. “Diagonal D2 flexion. I’ll be the therapist’s diagonal.” He stands, positions himself at my right side. This is the worst part—the choreography that puts his body in mine’s orbit. He threads his right arm under my shoulder, his hand cupping my scapula again. His left hand takes my wrist. To an observer, we’d look like dancers. His torso is parallel to mine, his hip nearly touching my ribcage. I can smell him—antiseptic soap, yes, but underneath, the same chalk-and-sweat that used to mean partnership. “Eyes on the diagram,” he instructs, though I already am. The infraspinatus muscle stares back, its fibers fanning across the scapula like a threat. “Follow my hand. Flexion, abduction, external rotation.” He moves my arm through the diagonal pattern, a smooth arc from hip to overhead. At the apex, when my arm is fully flexed and externally rotated, his chest presses against my lateral deltoid. I can feel his breathing. My skin rises in goosebumps beneath his scrub top’s contact. The pain is a bright star in the joint, but it’s dwarfed by the proximity, by the memory of his body moving with mine on rock, when touch meant trust and not this calibrated clinical assault. “Hold,” he says, his voice closer. “Feel the scapular upward rotation.” I feel everything. The stretch through my pectoralis minor, the anterior glide of my humeral head that threatens subluxation, the warmth of his breath near my temple. My left hand, the good one, grips the table edge until my knuckles whiten. “Now eccentric control on the way down.” He releases my wrist slightly, making my rotator cuff work to control the descent. The burn is exquisite. His hand on my scapula shifts, thumb pressing into the space between spine of scapula and clavicle—subacromial space—assessing for impingement. The pressure is direct, invasive, necessary. I suppress a sound. Two minutes left in the session. He steps back, the loss of his heat immediate as a cold front. “Final stretch. Supine sleeper stretch, self-assisted.” I roll onto my left side, bad shoulder up. He positions himself behind me, his knees against the table edge. “Bend your elbow to ninety. I’m going to apply overpressure to the forearm, not the hand. You control the intensity.” His hand covers mine on my forearm. We push together. The stretch through the posterior capsule is a deep, tearing sensation, like cloth ripping slowly. My forehead presses into the table padding. His other hand rests on my iliac crest, ostensibly to stabilize my pelvis, but the contact burns through my shorts. “Thirty seconds,” he says, and I can’t tell if he’s counting down the stretch or the time until he can stop touching me. The diagram watches. The muscles on the wall are silent, obedient. Mine scream. His hands are professional instruments, diagnostic tools, and yet my body—traitor, failure—responds to them with a memory older than injury. When he finally releases me, when the timer chirps its merciful end, we both exhale in unison. “Same time Thursday,” he says, already documenting, not looking at me. The distance is back, a chasm measured in diplomas and salvaged careers. I nod, flexing my ruined finger, feeling the grafted tendon slide beneath skin that will never forget his touch.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional technical mastery and precise adherence to the complex prompt requirements. The narrative successfully captures the perspective of a former athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy, with the physiotherapist being a former training partner. The anatomical precision is remarkable—every therapeutic technique, from passive external rotation to PNF diagonal patterns, is described with medical accuracy that grounds the narrative in authentic detail. The physical therapy session unfolds with meticulous spatial and anatomical coherence. The author demonstrates deep knowledge of rehabilitation techniques, precisely describing hand placements, joint angles, and therapeutic pressure points. The progression from shoulder assessment to finger work to complex movement patterns feels authentic and professionally accurate. The sexual tension is masterfully handled through restraint and professionalism rather than overt sexuality. The tension emerges from proximity, shared history, and the clinical intimacy of therapeutic touch. The protagonist's internal conflict between physical response and emotional resistance creates compelling psychological complexity. The prose achieves a clinical precision that mirrors the therapeutic setting while maintaining poetic resonance. Medical terminology is seamlessly integrated without becoming pedantic. The voice remains consistently bitter yet vulnerable throughout, with the protagonist's resentment toward recovery palpable in every interaction.
